entries.etymology: From the verb אָהַב (ahav), 'to love.' The root appears across Semitic languages. The noun אַהֲבָה represents the abstract quality or feeling of love.
entries.otUsage: This noun occurs 40 times in the OT. It describes: (1) romantic love (Song of Songs 2:4-5), (2) familial love (Gen 29:20), (3) friendship love (1 Sam 18:3), and (4) divine love (Jer 31:3). The verb form אָהַב is much more common (210x).

keyPassages.significance: The command to love God - showing that love can be commanded because it involves choice and action, not just feeling.
Love is as strong as death - expressing the powerful, unquenchable nature of true love.

entries.theologicalNote: Hebrew אַהֲבָה encompasses a broad range of love, from romantic to divine. Unlike ḥesed (covenant love), ahavah emphasizes the emotional affection aspect. God's ahavah for Israel is foundational to the covenant relationship.

entries.etymology: From שָׁלֵם (shalem), 'to be complete, sound.' Shalom is not merely absence of conflict but positive well-being, wholeness, and flourishing.
entries.otUsage: Occurs 237 times. Used as: (1) greeting/farewell (Gen 29:6), (2) state of well-being (Ps 4:8), (3) peace between people/nations (1 Kings 5:12), (4) covenant blessing (Num 6:26), (5) messianic promise (Isa 9:6-7).

keyPassages.hebrew: יִשָּׂא יְהוָה פָּנָיו אֵלֶיךָ וְיָשֵׂם לְךָ שָׁלוֹם
keyPassages.significance: The Aaronic blessing concludes with shalom - summarizing all covenant blessings.
The Messiah is the Prince of Peace - one who will establish perfect shalom.

entries.theologicalNote: Shalom represents the comprehensive blessing of covenant relationship with God. It encompasses physical health, material prosperity, relational harmony, and spiritual well-being. Sin disrupts shalom; redemption restores it.

relatedWords.relationship: Complete, whole - the root concept behind shalom
To make restitution, repay - restoring shalom

entries.etymology: From אָמַן (aman), 'to be firm, established.' Emet combines the ideas of truth (correspondence to reality) and faithfulness (reliability over time).
entries.otUsage: Occurs 127 times. Key uses: (1) truthful speech (Prov 12:19), (2) God's faithfulness (Ps 25:10), (3) God's word as truth (Ps 119:160), (4) paired with ḥesed as 'steadfast love and faithfulness' (Exod 34:6).

keyPassages.significance: God is abundant in steadfast love and truth - His character is reliable.
The sum of God's word is truth - Scripture is entirely reliable.

entries.theologicalNote: Emet describes what is stable, reliable, and trustworthy. When applied to God, it affirms that He keeps His promises and His words correspond to reality. Truth in Hebrew is not abstract but personal and relational.

relatedWords.relationship: So be it - affirming something as true and reliable

entries.etymology: The physical heart, extended metaphorically to the inner person. In Hebrew thought, the heart is the center of intellect, will, and emotion - not just feelings.
entries.otUsage: One of the most frequent words in the OT (850+ times). Refers to: (1) the physical organ (2 Sam 18:14), (2) emotions (Ps 13:2), (3) will and intention (Exod 35:29), (4) intellect and understanding (1 Kings 3:12), (5) moral character (Gen 6:5).

keyPassages.significance: Love God with all your heart - total devotion of the whole inner person.
Guard your heart - for it is the source of life and determines conduct.

entries.theologicalNote: The heart in Hebrew encompasses what we divide between heart (emotions), mind (intellect), and will (decisions). It is the control center of the whole person. This is why heart transformation is central to biblical religion.

relatedWords.relationship: Alternate form of heart - same meaning
Soul, life - the whole animated person

entries.etymology: From אָדוֹן (adon), 'lord, master.' The -ai ending is likely a first person suffix ('my lord') that became a divine title. Used as substitute pronunciation for YHWH.
entries.otUsage: Occurs 439 times. Used of: (1) human masters/lords (Gen 24:9), (2) God as sovereign Lord (Josh 3:11), (3) substitute for YHWH in Jewish reading tradition. Often combined with YHWH: 'Lord YHWH' (אֲדֹנָי יְהוִה).

keyPassages.significance: Isaiah sees Adonai on His throne - emphasizing divine sovereignty.
YHWH speaks to 'my Lord' - a messianic psalm cited by Jesus (Matt 22:44).

entries.theologicalNote: Adonai emphasizes God's lordship and sovereignty. Combined with YHWH, it expresses both God's covenant relationship (YHWH) and His absolute authority (Adonai). In Jewish tradition, Adonai is spoken when reading YHWH.

relatedWords.relationship: The covenant name of God - 'I AM'
Lord, master - used of human rulers

entries.etymology: From דָּבַר (davar), 'to speak.' The Hebrew concept unites word and reality - a word is not just sound but a thing that accomplishes something.
entries.otUsage: Extremely frequent (1,455x). Means both 'word' and 'thing/matter.' Used for: (1) human speech (Gen 11:1), (2) God's creative word (Gen 1:3), (3) prophetic word (Jer 1:4), (4) events/matters (Gen 22:1), (5) the Ten Words/Commandments (Exod 34:28).

keyPassages.significance: God's word creates - word and reality are united.

keyPassages.hebrew: כֵּן יִהְיֶה דְבָרִי אֲשֶׁר יֵצֵא מִפִּי
keyPassages.significance: God's word accomplishes His purpose - it is effective, not empty.

entries.theologicalNote: The Hebrew view of 'word' is dynamic - words do things. God's davar creates, reveals, and accomplishes. This theology of the word underlies the NT logos concept and the power of Scripture.

relatedWords.relationship: To say - simple speaking (vs. דָּבַר which implies content)
Word - more common in later/Aramaic texts

entries.etymology: From the root צדק denoting what is right, straight, or as it should be. Encompasses both ethical righteousness and legal justice.
entries.otUsage: Occurs 123 times (plus feminine צְדָקָה 159x). Used of: (1) ethical conduct (Deut 16:20), (2) just weights/measures (Lev 19:36), (3) legal justice (Ps 9:8), (4) divine attribute (Ps 89:14), (5) saving righteousness (Isa 51:5-6).

keyPassages.significance: Abraham believed and it was credited as righteousness - foundational for Paul's doctrine of justification.
Righteousness comes from God - it is His gift, not human achievement.

entries.theologicalNote: Tsedeq is both attribute and action. God is righteous (His character) and does righteousness (His actions). In Isaiah, God's righteousness becomes salvific - His righteous intervention to save His people. This prepares for NT imputed righteousness.

relatedWords.relationship: Righteous person - one who conforms to the standard
Justice, judgment - often paired with tsedeq

entries.etymology: From בָּרַךְ (barak), 'to bless, kneel.' The connection to kneeling suggests blessing involves both reception (kneeling before God) and transmission (God bending to bless).
entries.otUsage: Occurs 71 times. Used for: (1) patriarchal blessings (Gen 27:36), (2) covenant blessing (Deut 28:2), (3) praise to God (Ps 103:1), (4) gifts/presents (Gen 33:11), (5) the opposite of curse (Deut 11:26-28).

keyPassages.significance: God's promise to Abraham - he will be blessed and be a blessing.
The Aaronic blessing - the comprehensive blessing of God's people.

entries.theologicalNote: Blessing in the OT is not just well-wishing but effective divine power transmitted through words. God's blessing brings fruitfulness, success, and prosperity. The covenant is structured around blessing for obedience and curse for disobedience.

entries.etymology: From חָכַם (chakam), 'to be wise.' Encompasses practical skill, ethical insight, and intellectual understanding - not mere theoretical knowledge.
entries.otUsage: Occurs 153 times, concentrated in Proverbs, Job, and Ecclesiastes. Includes: (1) craftsmanship skill (Exod 28:3), (2) practical wisdom (Prov 1:2), (3) personified Wisdom (Prov 8), (4) divine wisdom (Job 28), (5) royal wisdom (1 Kings 3:28).

keyPassages.significance: The fear of YHWH is the beginning of knowledge - wisdom has a religious foundation.
Wisdom personified as present at creation - christological implications.

entries.theologicalNote: Biblical wisdom is not secular cleverness but skill for living according to God's design. It begins with reverence for God and is expressed in righteous conduct. Personified Wisdom in Proverbs 8 points forward to Christ, 'the wisdom of God' (1 Cor 1:24).

relatedWords.relationship: Understanding, insight - discernment aspect of wisdom

entries.shortDef: to sin, miss the mark, go wrong
entries.etymology: The basic meaning is 'to miss' a target (Judg 20:16). Applied ethically, it means missing God's standard - falling short of what He requires.
entries.otUsage: The root appears 595 times in various forms. Noun חַטָּאת (chattat) means 'sin' or 'sin offering.' Used of: (1) sins against God (Gen 39:9), (2) sins against people (Gen 42:22), (3) unintentional sins (Lev 4:2), (4) the sin offering that atones for sin.

keyPassages.significance: Sin crouches at the door - personifying sin as a predator.
David's confession - all sin is ultimately against God.

entries.theologicalNote: Chata is the most common word for sin, emphasizing failure to meet a standard. Unlike 'avon (guilt/iniquity) or pesha' (rebellion), chata focuses on the deviation from God's way. The same word for 'sin' and 'sin offering' shows that sin requires atonement.

relatedWords.relationship: Iniquity, guilt - emphasizes the twisted nature of sin

entries.etymology: From זָבַח (zavach), 'to slaughter, sacrifice.' Specifically denotes animal sacrifice, especially the peace/fellowship offering where the worshiper ate a portion.
entries.otUsage: Occurs 162 times. Primary uses: (1) peace offerings (Lev 3), (2) general term for sacrifice (Ps 40:6), (3) pagan sacrifices (2 Kings 10:19), (4) covenant meals (Exod 24:5). Distinguished from עֹלָה (burnt offering) which is wholly consumed.

keyPassages.hebrew: הַחֵפֶץ לַיהוָה בְּעֹלוֹת וּזְבָחִים כִּשְׁמֹעַ בְּקוֹל יְהוָה
keyPassages.significance: Obedience is better than sacrifice - inner attitude matters more than ritual.
The sacrifice God desires is a broken spirit - internal not merely external.

entries.theologicalNote: The sacrificial system taught that sin requires death (substitution) and that communion with God requires sacrifice. The peace offering (zebach shelamim) emphasized fellowship - sharing a meal with God. All sacrifices pointed forward to Christ's once-for-all sacrifice.

relatedWords.relationship: Burnt offering - wholly consumed, emphasizing total dedication
Offering, gift - general term for what is brought near to God

entries.etymology: The root has two meanings: (1) to shine, flash (Isa 13:10), (2) to praise, boast. 'Hallelujah' (הַלְלוּ־יָהּ) means 'Praise YHWH!'
entries.otUsage: Occurs 165 times in the Piel ('to praise'). Concentrated in Psalms (99x). Used for: (1) praising God (Ps 146-150), (2) human boasting (Prov 27:1), (3) the deranged acting 'mad' (1 Sam 21:13). The 'Hallel' Psalms (113-118) were sung at festivals.

keyPassages.significance: Let everything that has breath praise YHWH - the climax of the Psalter.
The opening of the Egyptian Hallel sung at Passover - the context of the Last Supper.

entries.theologicalNote: Praise is humanity's highest calling - we were made to glorify God. The Psalter structures worship around praise, moving from lament to praise. Hallelujah carries into the NT and will be the eternal song of the redeemed (Rev 19:1-6).

relatedWords.relationship: To give thanks, confess - often paired with halal

entries.etymology: Plural form of אֱלוֹהַּ (eloah). The plural is often called 'plural of majesty' when referring to the one true God. May derive from אֵל (el), 'might, power.'
entries.otUsage: Occurs 2,602 times - the most common word for God. Used for: (1) the true God (Gen 1:1), (2) false gods (Exod 20:3), (3) angels/divine beings (Ps 8:5), (4) judges/rulers (Ps 82:6). Context determines referent.

keyPassages.significance: In the beginning God created - establishing God as Creator and sovereign.
YHWH our God, YHWH is one - the Shema declaring monotheism.

entries.theologicalNote: Elohim emphasizes God's power and might. The plural form with singular verbs when referring to YHWH hints at the complexity of God's nature later revealed as Trinity. Elohim is the Creator, Judge, and Sovereign.

entries.shortDef: the LORD, the personal name of God
entries.etymology: The divine name, often called the Tetragrammaton (four letters). Related to הָיָה (hayah), 'to be.' God explained it as 'I AM WHO I AM' (Exod 3:14).
entries.otUsage: Occurs 6,828 times - the most frequent name for God. The personal, covenant name of Israel's God. Revealed to Moses at the burning bush. Jews avoid pronouncing it, saying 'Adonai' instead.

keyPassages.hebrew: אֶהְיֶה אֲשֶׁר אֶהְיֶה... יְהוָה אֱלֹהֵי אֲבֹתֵיכֶם
keyPassages.significance: I AM WHO I AM - God reveals His personal name and its meaning.
YHWH, YHWH, a God merciful and gracious - God proclaims His character.

entries.theologicalNote: YHWH is God's covenant name, emphasizing His personal relationship with Israel. It expresses His eternal self-existence and faithfulness. The name is so holy that it came to be unspoken, replaced by Adonai or HaShem.

relatedWords.relationship: Lord, Master - spoken in place of YHWH
To be - root of the divine name

entries.etymology: From אָדוֹן (adon), 'lord, master.' The suffix -ai is the first person possessive ('my'). Adonai literally means 'my Lord/Master.'
entries.otUsage: Occurs 439 times. Used: (1) for God as sovereign Lord, (2) as substitute when reading YHWH aloud, (3) in compound with YHWH as 'Lord GOD.' Emphasizes God's authority and our submission.

keyPassages.significance: I saw the Lord sitting on a throne - divine majesty and sovereignty.
O Lord GOD, what will you give me - Abraham addresses God as Master.

entries.theologicalNote: Adonai emphasizes God's sovereignty and lordship. As Lord, He has the right to command; as servants, we must obey. Using Adonai for YHWH expresses both reverence and submission.

relatedWords.relationship: Lord, master - used for human lords too
The divine name - Adonai substitutes in reading

entries.etymology: Ancient Semitic word for deity, used across Semitic languages. May relate to a root meaning 'power' or 'to be strong.'
entries.otUsage: Occurs 238 times. Used: (1) for the true God (Gen 14:18), (2) in divine names (El Shaddai, El Elyon), (3) for false gods, (4) for mighty men/things. Often in poetry and compound names.

keyPassages.significance: God Most High, possessor of heaven and earth - Melchizedek's blessing.
Mighty God - messianic title emphasizing divine power.

entries.theologicalNote: El emphasizes God's might and power. It appears in compound names: El Shaddai (God Almighty), El Elyon (God Most High), El Olam (Everlasting God). Many Israelite names contain El (Daniel, Michael, Israel).

relatedWords.relationship: Gods, mighty ones - plural of El

entries.etymology: Shaddai's origin is debated: possibly from שַׁד (shad), 'breast' (nourishing), or שָׁדַד (shadad), 'to overpower,' or Akkadian 'mountain.' Traditionally rendered 'Almighty.'
entries.otUsage: El Shaddai occurs 7 times; Shaddai alone 41 times (31 in Job). The patriarchal name for God (Exod 6:3). Emphasizes God's power to fulfill promises and provide.

keyPassages.significance: I am God Almighty; walk before me - covenant establishment with Abraham.
I appeared to Abraham... as El Shaddai - the patriarchal revelation.

entries.theologicalNote: El Shaddai was the primary name by which the patriarchs knew God. It emphasizes His almighty power and sufficiency to fulfill His promises despite impossible circumstances (Sarah's barrenness, etc.).

entries.etymology: From עָלָה (alah), 'to go up, ascend.' Elyon means 'highest, uppermost.' Used as divine title: the God who is above all.
entries.otUsage: Occurs 53 times. Often in El Elyon (God Most High). Used: (1) for YHWH as supreme (Ps 83:18), (2) in Melchizedek's blessing (Gen 14), (3) in Daniel's Aramaic (Dan 4:17). Emphasizes God's supremacy over all gods and powers.

keyPassages.hebrew: אַתָּה שִׁמְךָ יְהוָה לְבַדֶּךָ עֶלְיוֹן עַל־כָּל־הָאָרֶץ
keyPassages.significance: You alone are YHWH, the Most High over all the earth.
The Most High rules the kingdom of mankind - God's sovereignty over nations.

entries.theologicalNote: Elyon declares God's absolute supremacy. He is higher than all other so-called gods, higher than all earthly powers. This title was used in dialogue with pagans (Melchizedek, Nebuchadnezzar) to declare YHWH's universal lordship.

relatedWords.relationship: To go up - root meaning height

entries.etymology: From קָדַשׁ (qadash), 'to be set apart, consecrated.' The root idea is separation - God is separate from all creation in His moral perfection.
entries.otUsage: Occurs 116 times as adjective. 'Holy One of Israel' (קְדוֹשׁ יִשְׂרָאֵל) appears 31 times in Isaiah. Describes: (1) God Himself (Isa 6:3), (2) things consecrated to God, (3) Israel as set apart for God.

keyPassages.significance: Holy, holy, holy is YHWH of hosts - the threefold declaration of absolute holiness.

keyPassages.hebrew: קְדֹשִׁים תִּהְיוּ כִּי קָדוֹשׁ אֲנִי יְהוָה
keyPassages.significance: Be holy, for I YHWH your God am holy - the call to reflect God's character.

entries.theologicalNote: Holiness is God's fundamental attribute - His utter uniqueness and moral perfection. Because God is holy, His people must be holy. Holiness involves both separation from sin and consecration to God.

entries.etymology: Plural of צָבָא (tsava), 'army, warfare, service.' YHWH Tseva'ot - 'LORD of Hosts' - is a divine title emphasizing God's command over heavenly and earthly armies.
entries.otUsage: Occurs 486 times. YHWH Tseva'ot appears 284 times, concentrated in Prophets (especially Isaiah, Jeremiah, Haggai, Zechariah, Malachi). 'Hosts' refers to angelic armies, stars, or Israel's armies.

keyPassages.hebrew: בְּשֵׁם יְהוָה צְבָאוֹת אֱלֹהֵי מַעַרְכוֹת יִשְׂרָאֵל
keyPassages.significance: In the name of YHWH of Hosts, God of the armies of Israel - David vs Goliath.
YHWH of Hosts, He is the King of Glory.

entries.theologicalNote: This title emphasizes God's sovereign power over all cosmic forces. He commands the stars (His army), the angels (His hosts), and fights for Israel. It's especially prominent in prophetic judgment contexts.

entries.etymology: The cardinal number one. Can mean numerical one or unified one (as in Gen 2:24, 'one flesh' from two persons).
entries.otUsage: Occurs 960 times. Used: (1) numerical one, (2) unified one (Gen 2:24), (3) sole/only (Deut 6:4), (4) same/alike. Central to the Shema's declaration of God's unity.

keyPassages.significance: YHWH our God, YHWH is one - Israel's creed of monotheism.
They shall become one flesh - compound unity from two.

entries.theologicalNote: Echad in the Shema may mean 'YHWH alone' (no other gods) or 'YHWH is unified.' Unlike yachid (absolute one), echad can denote compound unity, which some see as compatible with Trinity.

entries.etymology: From גָּדַל (gadal), 'to grow, become great.' Can describe physical size, importance, intensity, or age.
entries.otUsage: Occurs 528 times. Applied to God: 'the great God' (Deut 10:17), 'great and awesome' (Neh 1:5). Also: great city, great king, great sin, great light. Comparative and superlative uses.

keyPassages.hebrew: כִּי יְהוָה אֱלֹהֵיכֶם הוּא אֱלֹהֵי הָאֱלֹהִים וַאֲדֹנֵי הָאֲדֹנִים הָאֵל הַגָּדֹל
keyPassages.significance: YHWH your God is God of gods... the great, mighty, awesome God.

keyPassages.hebrew: כִּי אֵל גָּדוֹל יְהוָה וּמֶלֶךְ גָּדוֹל עַל־כָּל־אֱלֹהִים
keyPassages.significance: YHWH is a great God and a great King above all gods.

entries.theologicalNote: God's greatness exceeds all comparison. He is great in power, wisdom, love, and faithfulness. His greatness demands our worship and trust. Great things are expected from a great God.

entries.etymology: From חָנַן (chanan), 'to show favor, be gracious.' Chen (grace) is the related noun. Channun is used exclusively of God in the OT.
entries.otUsage: Occurs 13 times - always describing God. Part of the divine self-revelation in Exodus 34:6. Often paired with 'merciful' (rachum). Shows God's disposition to show unmerited favor.

keyPassages.significance: YHWH, YHWH, a God merciful and gracious - God's self-description.
Gracious is YHWH and righteous - combining grace with justice.

entries.theologicalNote: God's graciousness means He shows favor not based on merit. He inclines toward the needy, hears the cry of the oppressed. This is pure grace - unearned, undeserved, freely given.

relatedWords.relationship: To be gracious, show favor - verb

entries.etymology: From רֶחֶם (rechem), 'womb.' Rachum describes the deep compassion a mother feels for her child - visceral, tender mercy.
entries.otUsage: Occurs 13 times - always of God. Paired with channun (gracious) in the divine self-revelation. This womb-compassion shows God's tender, nurturing love for His people.

keyPassages.significance: A God merciful and gracious - God's fundamental character.
As a father has compassion on children, YHWH has compassion.

entries.theologicalNote: God's compassion is not distant pity but deep, maternal-like feeling. The womb connection shows mercy as life-giving and nurturing. God feels for His suffering people with intense tenderness.

entries.etymology: From שׁום/שִׂים (sum/sim), 'to set, place.' A name identifies and represents a person's character and reputation.
entries.otUsage: Occurs 864 times. God's name represents His character, presence, and authority. 'For My name's sake' means 'because of who I am.' The temple was where God placed His name.

keyPassages.significance: You shall not take the name of YHWH your God in vain.
The name of YHWH is a strong tower - His name represents His protection.

entries.theologicalNote: In Hebrew thought, a name was not just a label but expressed essential character. God's name is His reputation, His revealed character. To honor His name is to honor who He is.

relatedWords.relationship: To call, name - verb for naming

entries.etymology: From a root meaning 'to send.' A malak is a sent one - whether human messenger or divine angel. Context determines which.
entries.otUsage: Occurs 213 times. Used for: (1) human messengers (Gen 32:3), (2) prophets (Hag 1:13), (3) priests (Mal 2:7), (4) angels, (5) 'The Angel of YHWH' - a special theophanic figure.

keyPassages.significance: The Angel of YHWH found Hagar - speaks as God Himself.
Bless YHWH, His angels, mighty in strength - heavenly worship.

entries.theologicalNote: The 'Angel of YHWH' often speaks as God and is worshiped, suggesting a pre-incarnate appearance of Christ. Regular angels are ministering spirits serving God and His people.

relatedWords.relationship: To send - related to messenger function
To minister, serve - what angels do

entries.etymology: From a root meaning 'to breathe.' Ruach can mean wind, breath, spirit, or Spirit depending on context. The Spirit of God is His active presence and power.
entries.otUsage: Occurs 378 times. Ruach Elohim/YHWH: (1) empowers for service (Judg 14:6), (2) inspires prophecy (1 Sam 19:20), (3) brings life (Gen 2:7), (4) creates (Gen 1:2). Increasingly personal in later texts.

keyPassages.significance: The Spirit of God hovered over the waters - active in creation.
The Spirit of YHWH shall rest on Him - messianic empowerment.

entries.theologicalNote: God's Spirit is His active presence in the world. The Spirit empowers, transforms, and gives life. OT hints at personality develop into the NT revelation of the Spirit as third Person of the Trinity.

entries.etymology: Always plural in Hebrew. From פָּנָה (panah), 'to turn.' The face is what turns toward or away from someone.
entries.otUsage: Occurs 2,126 times. God's panim: (1) His manifest presence (Exod 33:14), (2) His favor when face shines (Num 6:25), (3) His judgment when face is hidden (Ps 13:1). 'Before the face of YHWH' means in His presence.

keyPassages.significance: My presence (face) will go with you - God's personal accompaniment.

keyPassages.hebrew: יָאֵר יְהוָה פָּנָיו אֵלֶיךָ... יִשָּׂא יְהוָה פָּנָיו אֵלֶיךָ
keyPassages.significance: YHWH make His face shine on you... lift His face to you - blessing.

entries.theologicalNote: God's face represents His personal presence and favor. When His face shines, blessing comes. When He hides His face, distress follows. Seeking God's face means pursuing intimate relationship.

relatedWords.relationship: Before, in the presence of - preposition

entries.etymology: Root meaning 'to work, serve.' The noun eved (servant) comes from this. Worship is fundamentally service to God.
entries.otUsage: Occurs 289 times. Meanings: (1) work/labor (Gen 2:15), (2) serve someone (Gen 29:15), (3) serve God/worship (Exod 3:12), (4) serve idols (Exod 20:5). True worship is whole-life service.

keyPassages.significance: You shall serve God on this mountain - worship as purpose of exodus.
As for me and my house, we will serve YHWH - the choice to worship.

entries.theologicalNote: Biblical worship is not merely ritual but whole-life service. We were freed from slavery to Pharaoh to serve God. The same word for labor describes worship - both require effort and dedication.

entries.etymology: Root meaning 'to bow, stoop.' Physical posture expressing submission, reverence, and homage.
entries.otUsage: Occurs 172 times. Used for: (1) worship of God (Gen 22:5), (2) bowing to people in respect (Gen 23:7), (3) idol worship (forbidden, Exod 20:5). Physical prostration expressing spiritual submission.

keyPassages.significance: You shall not bow to them or serve them - exclusive worship of YHWH.
Come, let us worship and bow down - invitation to humble worship.

entries.theologicalNote: Prostration was the most profound physical expression of worship - face to ground. It symbolized complete submission and reverence. True worship involves bowing the heart, not just the body.

entries.etymology: Root meaning 'to be afraid, stand in awe.' Yir'ah (fear) is the noun. 'Fear of YHWH' is reverent awe, not terror.
entries.otUsage: Occurs 317 times. Two aspects: (1) terror before danger (Gen 3:10), (2) reverent awe before God (Prov 1:7). Fear of YHWH is the beginning of wisdom - not cringing fear but awe-filled respect.

keyPassages.significance: Fear of YHWH is the beginning of knowledge - foundation of wisdom.
You shall fear YHWH your God - commanded reverence.

entries.theologicalNote: Fear of YHWH is the proper response to His holiness and majesty. It combines awe, reverence, trust, and obedience. It's not terror but profound respect that leads to righteousness.

entries.etymology: Root meaning 'to make music, sing praises.' Mizmor (psalm) derives from this root. Associated with instrumental accompaniment.
entries.otUsage: Occurs 45 times. Concentrated in Psalms. Always in praise contexts. Used with instruments (Ps 33:2), with the whole being (Ps 57:7), to YHWH's name (Ps 18:49).

keyPassages.hebrew: זַמְּרוּ אֱלֹהִים זַמֵּרוּ זַמְּרוּ לְמַלְכֵּנוּ זַמֵּרוּ
keyPassages.significance: Sing praises to God, sing praises! - emphatic call to musical worship.

keyPassages.hebrew: הוֹדוּ לַיהוָה בְּכִנּוֹר בְּנֵבֶל עָשׂוֹר זַמְּרוּ־לוֹ
keyPassages.significance: Give thanks with the lyre; with ten-stringed harp make melody to Him.

entries.theologicalNote: Musical worship is integral to biblical worship. Zamar implies joyful, skillful praise with instruments. The Psalms were Israel's hymnbook, to be sung, not just read.

relatedWords.relationship: Psalm, song - noun from this root

entries.etymology: Related to יָד (yad), 'hand.' The Hiphil (hodah) may suggest 'throwing out the hands' in praise. Combines thanksgiving and confession.
entries.otUsage: Occurs 111 times. Two main senses: (1) thank/praise God (Ps 136), (2) confess sin (Prov 28:13). Todah (thanksgiving offering, Lev 7:12) and hodah (praise) derive from this root.

keyPassages.significance: Give thanks to YHWH for He is good - opening of the Great Hallel.

keyPassages.hebrew: הוֹדוּ לַיהוָה כִּי טוֹב כִּי לְעוֹלָם חַסְדּוֹ
keyPassages.significance: Give thanks to YHWH, for He is good; His steadfast love endures forever.

entries.theologicalNote: Yadah combines thanksgiving for what God does with praise for who He is. It also includes confession - publicly declaring truth about God and ourselves. The same word for praising God is used for confessing sin.

entries.etymology: Related to בֶּרֶךְ (berek), 'knee.' Blessing involves kneeling. Blessing from God gives life; blessing God means praising Him.
entries.otUsage: Occurs 327 times. Directions: (1) God blesses humans (Gen 1:22), (2) humans bless God (Ps 103:1), (3) humans bless humans (Gen 27). Blessing is more than wish - it's effective speech.

keyPassages.significance: I will bless you... be a blessing - Abrahamic blessing for the world.
Bless YHWH, O my soul - the soul blessing God in worship.

entries.theologicalNote: God's blessing brings life, fertility, prosperity, and success. Human blessing of God is praise acknowledging His goodness. Blessing is not magic but relational - the powerful blessing the dependent.

entries.shortDef: to be holy, set apart, consecrate
entries.etymology: The verb form of the root giving qodesh (holiness) and qadosh (holy). To qadash is to set apart for sacred use.
entries.otUsage: Occurs 171 times. Used for: (1) God sanctifying Himself (Ezek 36:23), (2) people being sanctified (Exod 19:10), (3) consecrating objects (Exod 40:9), (4) observing holy times (Gen 2:3). Making or declaring holy.

keyPassages.hebrew: וְהִתְקַדִּשְׁתֶּם וִהְיִיתֶם קְדֹשִׁים כִּי אֲנִי יְהוָה אֱלֹהֵיכֶם
keyPassages.significance: Consecrate yourselves and be holy, for I am YHWH your God.

keyPassages.hebrew: וַיְבָרֶךְ אֱלֹהִים אֶת־יוֹם הַשְּׁבִיעִי וַיְקַדֵּשׁ אֹתוֹ
keyPassages.significance: God blessed the seventh day and made it holy - first sanctification.

entries.theologicalNote: Sanctification means setting apart from common use for God's purposes. God sanctifies His people; we also must consecrate ourselves. Both divine action and human response are required.

entries.etymology: Root meaning 'to judge, intervene.' Hitpael (reflexive) means to intercede, make supplication. Tefillah (prayer) comes from this root.
entries.otUsage: Occurs 84 times. The main word for prayer. Used for: (1) personal prayer (1 Sam 1:10), (2) intercessory prayer (Gen 20:7), (3) temple prayer (1 Kings 8:30). Prayer as intervention with God.

keyPassages.significance: She prayed to YHWH and wept bitterly - Hannah's desperate prayer.

keyPassages.hebrew: וּזִמְנִין תְּלָתָה בְיוֹמָא הוּא בָּרֵךְ עַל־בִּרְכוֹהִי וּמְצַלֵּא
keyPassages.significance: Three times a day he prayed - Daniel's faithful prayer practice.

entries.theologicalNote: Prayer is communication with God - praise, confession, thanksgiving, supplication. The Hitpael form suggests prayer involves examining oneself before God. Prayer is access to the divine throne.

relatedWords.relationship: To plead for grace - related to supplication

entries.etymology: From נָדַר (nadar), 'to vow.' A neder is a conditional promise made to God, usually in exchange for divine help.
entries.otUsage: Occurs 60 times. Types: (1) conditional vow (Gen 28:20), (2) vow of abstinence (Num 6 - Nazirite), (3) vow offerings (Lev 7:16). Vows must be fulfilled (Eccl 5:4-5).

keyPassages.significance: Jacob made a vow - if God protects, YHWH will be his God.

keyPassages.hebrew: כַּאֲשֶׁר תִּדֹּר נֶדֶר לֵאלֹהִים אַל־תְּאַחֵר לְשַׁלְּמוֹ
keyPassages.significance: When you vow to God, don't delay to pay it - vows are binding.

entries.theologicalNote: Vows were solemn commitments to God. Better not to vow than to vow and not fulfill (Eccl 5:5). Vows expressed devotion but required careful consideration. They were voluntary but binding once made.

entries.etymology: From קָרַב (qarav), 'to draw near.' A qorban is what is brought near to God - an offering that allows approach to the holy.
entries.otUsage: Occurs 82 times, mostly in Leviticus and Numbers. General term for offerings brought to the altar. Various types: burnt, grain, peace, sin, guilt. Each enabled approach to God.

keyPassages.significance: When anyone brings an offering to YHWH - the general introduction.
Corban - Jesus mentions this Hebrew term in teaching on vows.

entries.theologicalNote: Every qorban facilitated drawing near to God. Sin creates distance; offerings bridge the gap. The system taught that access to God requires sacrifice - ultimately fulfilled in Christ's once-for-all offering.

relatedWords.relationship: To draw near - the root idea

entries.etymology: From עָלָה (alah), 'to go up, ascend.' The olah goes up entirely in smoke to God - nothing is retained by worshiper or priest.
entries.otUsage: Occurs 286 times. The most common sacrifice, offered daily (tamid). Distinctive: entirely consumed on the altar. Expressed total dedication, consecration, and general atonement.

keyPassages.significance: A burnt offering... it shall be accepted for him to make atonement.
Offer him as a burnt offering - the binding of Isaac.

entries.theologicalNote: The olah symbolized complete dedication to God. Nothing held back. The smoke ascending represented the gift going up to heaven. The daily tamid sacrifice was an olah, maintaining constant worship.

relatedWords.relationship: To go up, ascend - root verb

entries.etymology: From חָטָא (chata), 'to sin, miss.' The same word means both 'sin' and 'sin offering' - the offering that deals with sin.
entries.otUsage: Occurs 298 times. Two meanings: (1) sin itself (Gen 4:7), (2) sacrifice for sin (Lev 4:3). The chattat purified from sin's contamination and restored relationship.

keyPassages.hebrew: וְהִקְרִיב עַל־חַטָּאתוֹ אֲשֶׁר חָטָא פַּר בֶּן־בָּקָר תָּמִים
keyPassages.significance: He shall offer for his sin a bull without blemish as a sin offering.
He made Him who knew no sin to be sin (hamartia/chattat) for us.

entries.theologicalNote: The chattat addressed sin's pollution, not just guilt. Blood purified the sanctuary contaminated by sin. Christ became our chattat - the offering that deals with sin completely.

relatedWords.relationship: To sin, miss - the root verb

entries.etymology: From זָבַח (zabach), 'to slaughter, sacrifice.' The mizbeach is the place where sacrifices are offered.
entries.otUsage: Occurs 402 times. Altars from patriarchs to temple. Functions: (1) place of sacrifice, (2) memorial marker (Gen 12:7), (3) place of meeting God. The tabernacle/temple had bronze and gold altars.

keyPassages.significance: He built there an altar to YHWH - Abraham's worship at Shechem.
Make for Me an altar of earth - simple instructions for worship.

entries.theologicalNote: The altar was the place of divine-human meeting through sacrifice. It represented giving life to God. The bronze altar (burnt offerings) and golden altar (incense) served different purposes in tabernacle worship.

relatedWords.relationship: Horn - altars had horns at corners

entries.etymology: Uncertain. Perhaps from בָּרָה (barah), 'to eat' (covenant meals) or related to 'cutting' (cut a covenant). Covenants were formalized relationships.
entries.otUsage: Occurs 287 times. Types: (1) divine-human (Gen 15, 17; Exod 19-24), (2) human-human (Gen 21:27), (3) marriage (Mal 2:14). God's covenants: Noahic, Abrahamic, Mosaic, Davidic, New.

keyPassages.hebrew: בַּיּוֹם הַהוּא כָּרַת יְהוָה אֶת־אַבְרָם בְּרִית
keyPassages.significance: That day YHWH cut a covenant with Abram - formal commitment.

keyPassages.hebrew: הִנֵּה יָמִים בָּאִים... וְכָרַתִּי אֶת־בֵּית יִשְׂרָאֵל... בְּרִית חֲדָשָׁה
keyPassages.significance: Days are coming when I will make a new covenant with Israel.

entries.theologicalNote: Covenant is central to biblical theology. God relates to His people through covenant - binding promises with obligations. The new covenant writes law on hearts, making possible what the old commanded.

entries.etymology: Uncertain origin. Perhaps related to חָסִיד (chasid), 'faithful one.' Chesed is covenant love - loyal, enduring commitment.
entries.otUsage: Occurs 248 times. God's chesed: (1) endures forever (Ps 136), (2) paired with emet (truth), (3) basis for appeal (Ps 51:1). Human chesed: kindness, loyalty. Difficult to translate - 'steadfast love' captures faithfulness aspect.

keyPassages.hebrew: הוֹדוּ לַיהוָה כִּי־טוֹב כִּי לְעוֹלָם חַסְדּוֹ
keyPassages.significance: Give thanks to YHWH, for He is good; His steadfast love endures forever.
Love chesed (mercy/kindness) - what God requires.

entries.theologicalNote: Chesed is God's covenant loyalty - faithful love that perseveres despite unfaithfulness. It's active, not passive. God shows chesed; we are to love chesed. It combines love, mercy, faithfulness, and loyalty.

relatedWords.relationship: Faithful one - one who practices chesed

entries.etymology: From אָמַן (aman), 'to be firm, reliable.' Related to amen and emet. Emunah is firmness, reliability, faithfulness.
entries.otUsage: Occurs 49 times. Describes: (1) God's faithfulness (Lam 3:23), (2) human faithfulness (Hab 2:4), (3) steady hands (Exod 17:12), (4) trustworthiness. Foundation of covenant relationship.

keyPassages.significance: The righteous shall live by his faith/faithfulness - foundational text.
Great is Your faithfulness - hymn of hope in suffering.

entries.theologicalNote: Emunah includes both God's faithfulness to us and our faith in Him. The righteous live by emunah - trusting God's reliability and being faithful ourselves. It's the basis for hope when circumstances are dark.

relatedWords.relationship: To be firm, believe - root verb

entries.etymology: Root meaning 'to remember, bring to mind.' Zikkaron (memorial) comes from this. Remembering implies action, not just mental recall.
entries.otUsage: Occurs 233 times. When God remembers: (1) covenant (Gen 9:15), (2) His people (Gen 8:1), (3) to act in mercy. When humans remember: (1) Sabbath (Exod 20:8), (2) YHWH (Deut 8:18), (3) past salvation (Deut 5:15).

keyPassages.significance: God remembered Noah - divine action on Noah's behalf.
God remembered His covenant - leading to the exodus.

entries.theologicalNote: Biblical remembering means bringing to mind with intent to act. When God remembers, He acts. When we remember, we respond. Memorials (Passover, stones) ensure remembering across generations.

entries.etymology: From בָּרַךְ (barak), 'to bless.' A berakah is both the act of blessing and the prosperity that results from divine favor.
entries.otUsage: Occurs 71 times. Types: (1) God's blessing bringing prosperity (Deut 28:2-8), (2) parental blessing (Gen 27), (3) gift/present (Gen 33:11), (4) praise to God. Covenant blessings vs curses (Deut 28).

keyPassages.significance: I will bless you... be a blessing - Abraham's mission.
All these blessings shall come upon you - covenant obedience.

entries.theologicalNote: Blessing is God's favor flowing into life. It's more than material - it's relationship, presence, purpose. The covenant promised blessings for obedience. Through Abraham, blessing extends to all nations.

entries.etymology: From קָלַל (qalal), 'to be light, trivial.' To curse is to treat as worthless, invoke harm. The opposite of blessing.
entries.otUsage: Occurs 33 times. Sources: (1) God curses sin (Gen 3:14, 17), (2) covenant curses for disobedience (Deut 28:15-68), (3) human curses (Gen 27:12). The curse represents covenant breach consequences.

keyPassages.significance: All these curses shall come upon you - covenant disobedience.
The one cursing you I will curse - protection for Abraham.

entries.theologicalNote: Covenant curses show consequences of unfaithfulness. The blessings and curses of Deuteronomy 28 frame covenant choice. Christ became a curse for us (Gal 3:13), bearing curse's full weight.

relatedWords.relationship: To curse, be light - root verb

entries.etymology: Root meaning 'to take possession.' Can mean inheriting from parents or dispossessing enemies. Both ideas of taking what becomes yours.
entries.otUsage: Occurs 232 times. Central to conquest narratives. Used for: (1) taking the land (Deut 1:8), (2) dispossessing nations (Deut 9:1), (3) inheriting property (Deut 21:16), (4) divine gift of land.

keyPassages.significance: Go in and possess the land - command to take inheritance.
The meek shall inherit the earth - eschatological promise.

entries.theologicalNote: The land was Israel's covenant inheritance. Possessing it required faith and obedience. The concept expands eschatologically - the meek inherit the earth, believers inherit the kingdom.

entries.etymology: From נָחַל (nachal), 'to inherit.' The nachalah is the inherited portion, especially land given by lot.
entries.otUsage: Occurs 222 times. Key uses: (1) tribal land allotments (Josh 13-21), (2) Israel as YHWH's inheritance (Deut 32:9), (3) YHWH as Levites' inheritance (Num 18:20). Land and Lord as inheritance.

keyPassages.hebrew: כִּי חֵלֶק יְהוָה עַמּוֹ יַעֲקֹב חֶבֶל נַחֲלָתוֹ
keyPassages.significance: YHWH's portion is His people; Jacob is His inheritance.
YHWH is my portion and cup - God Himself as inheritance.

entries.theologicalNote: Inheritance language shows covenant blessings are permanent gifts. Each tribe had its nachalah. But the highest inheritance is YHWH Himself - He is our portion forever.

entries.etymology: From אוּת/אָתָה (ut/atah), meaning uncertain. An ot is a visible mark or signal pointing to something.
entries.otUsage: Occurs 79 times. Types: (1) covenant signs (rainbow, circumcision, Sabbath), (2) miracles (Exod 4:8), (3) prophetic signs (Isa 7:14), (4) warnings (Deut 28:46). Signs confirm God's word and promises.

keyPassages.significance: This is the sign of the covenant - the rainbow after the flood.

keyPassages.hebrew: אַךְ אֶת־שַׁבְּתֹתַי תִּשְׁמֹרוּ כִּי אוֹת הִוא
keyPassages.significance: Keep My Sabbaths, for it is a sign between Me and you.

entries.theologicalNote: Covenant signs are visible reminders of invisible realities. They don't create the covenant but confirm it. Signs point beyond themselves to God's promises and faithfulness.

relatedWords.relationship: Wonder, portent - often paired with ot

entries.etymology: One of the earliest words in any language - baby talk (like 'abba'). Universal across Semitic languages.
entries.otUsage: Occurs 1,210 times. Used for: (1) biological father (Gen 2:24), (2) ancestor (Gen 28:13), (3) founder/originator (Gen 4:20-21), (4) God as Father (Isa 64:8), (5) respect title (2 Kings 2:12). Patriarchal significance.

keyPassages.significance: But now, YHWH, You are our Father - God as Father.

keyPassages.hebrew: בֵּן יְכַבֵּד אָב... וְאִם־אָב אָנִי אַיֵּה כְבוֹדִי
keyPassages.significance: A son honors his father... If I am a Father, where is My honor?

entries.theologicalNote: Father expresses both authority and intimacy. God as Father shows His care, provision, and discipline. 'Father Abraham' shows covenant continuity. The 'God of our fathers' connects generations.

entries.etymology: From יָרָה (yarah) - to throw, shoot, point, teach. Torah is that which is pointed out, directed instruction. Root suggests guidance toward a target.
entries.otUsage: Occurs 223 times. Refers to: (1) specific instruction (Lev 6:9), (2) the Mosaic law (Josh 1:8), (3) priestly instruction (Mal 2:6-7), (4) parental teaching (Prov 1:8). Increasingly refers to the Pentateuch.

keyPassages.significance: Moses wrote this Torah - the law as written document.
How I love Your Torah! It is my meditation all day.

entries.theologicalNote: Torah is not merely rules but God's gracious instruction for life. It reveals God's character and shows the path of blessing. Reading Torah is an act of worship and relationship with the Lawgiver.

entries.etymology: From צָוָה (tsavah) - to command. A mitsvah is a specific divine directive, an authoritative order to be obeyed.
entries.otUsage: Occurs 181 times. Used for: (1) divine commands (Deut 6:1), (2) royal decrees (Esth 3:3), (3) specific laws (Num 15:31). Often plural 'mitsvot' for the commandments as a body.

keyPassages.significance: This is the commandment, the statutes and judgments.
For the commandment is a lamp and the Torah is light.

entries.theologicalNote: Mitsvot are expressions of God's will for His people. Keeping commandments is not legalism but loving response to God's grace. Each mitsvah is an opportunity to connect with God.

entries.etymology: From חָקַק (chaqaq) - to cut in, inscribe, decree. A choq is something engraved, permanently established, often without stated rationale.
entries.otUsage: Occurs 131 times. Used for: (1) divine decrees (Lev 10:13), (2) nature's laws (Jer 33:25), (3) customs (Judg 11:39), (4) allotted portion (Prov 30:8). Suggests permanence and authority.

keyPassages.significance: For it is your statute and your sons' statute.
Oh that my ways were directed to keep Your statutes!

entries.theologicalNote: Chuqqim often refer to laws without obvious rational explanation - they test obedience beyond understanding. Examples include dietary laws and red heifer. They teach trust in God's wisdom.

entries.etymology: From שָׁפַט (shaphat) - to judge. Mishpat is the verdict, the legal decision, the right order established by judgment.
entries.otUsage: Occurs 425 times. Means: (1) judicial decision (Deut 17:9), (2) justice (Mic 6:8), (3) legal right (Num 27:5), (4) manner/custom (1 Sam 8:9), (5) case law (Exod 21:1). Very versatile.

keyPassages.hebrew: וּמָה־יְהוָה דּוֹרֵשׁ מִמְּךָ כִּי אִם־עֲשׂוֹת מִשְׁפָּט
keyPassages.significance: What does YHWH require of you but to do justice?
Shall not the Judge of all the earth do what is just?

entries.theologicalNote: Mishpat combines legal procedure with moral outcome. God's mishpat establishes right order. Social justice (mishpat) for the poor is central to prophetic ethics.

entries.etymology: From עוּד (ud) - to return, repeat, testify. Edut is the repeated affirmation, the solemn declaration that bears witness.
entries.otUsage: Occurs 61 times. Refers to: (1) the tablets of law (Exod 25:16), (2) the ark (Exod 25:22), (3) divine declarations (Ps 19:7), (4) covenant stipulations (Ps 119:2). Often 'edot' plural.

keyPassages.hebrew: וְנָתַתָּ אֶת־הַכַּפֹּרֶת עַל־הָאָרֹן... וְאֶל־הָאָרֹן תִּתֵּן אֶת־הָעֵדֻת
keyPassages.significance: Put the mercy seat on the ark... put the Testimony in the ark.
Your testimonies are my delight and my counselors.

entries.theologicalNote: The edut testifies to God's character and covenant. The 'ark of the testimony' contains God's witness to Israel. His testimonies guide and delight the faithful.

entries.etymology: Basic Semitic root for auditory perception. In Hebrew, hearing implies responding - true hearing leads to obedience.
entries.otUsage: Occurs 1,165 times - one of the most common verbs. Means: (1) perceive sound (Gen 3:8), (2) understand (Gen 11:7), (3) obey (Deut 6:4), (4) grant request (Gen 17:20). 'Hear!' is 'Obey!'

keyPassages.hebrew: שְׁמַע יִשְׂרָאֵל יְהוָה אֱלֹהֵינוּ יְהוָה אֶחָד
keyPassages.significance: Hear, O Israel: YHWH our God, YHWH is one!
Behold, to obey is better than sacrifice.

entries.theologicalNote: The Shema (Deut 6:4) is Israel's foundational confession. Hebrew hearing is not passive - it demands response. To truly hear God is to obey Him.

entries.etymology: To hedge about, protect. Suggests vigilant attention and protective action - like a watchman guarding walls.
entries.otUsage: Occurs 469 times. Used for: (1) guarding (Gen 2:15), (2) observing commands (Exod 20:6), (3) protecting (Num 6:24), (4) watching (1 Sam 19:11), (5) keeping covenant (Gen 17:9).

keyPassages.significance: YHWH bless you and keep you - priestly blessing.
YHWH will keep you from all evil; He will keep your soul.

entries.theologicalNote: Keeping God's commands is response to His keeping us. Adam was to 'keep' the garden (Gen 2:15). God is the ultimate Keeper of Israel who neither slumbers nor sleeps.

entries.etymology: Basic action verb - to work, produce, accomplish. Unlike bara (divine creation), asah is ordinary making or doing.
entries.otUsage: Occurs 2,633 times - extremely common. Means: (1) make (Gen 1:7), (2) do (Gen 18:19), (3) produce (Gen 1:11), (4) act (Gen 39:22), (5) observe (Exod 31:16). Versatile action word.

keyPassages.significance: All that YHWH has spoken we will do and obey.
To do justice and love mercy...

entries.theologicalNote: Israel's response to covenant is to 'do' God's word. Faith expresses itself in doing. God both speaks and does - His word accomplishes His purpose.

entries.etymology: Basic verb of locomotion. Metaphorically describes one's way of life, conduct, manner of living.
entries.otUsage: Occurs 1,554 times. Means: (1) walk physically (Gen 3:8), (2) go (Gen 12:1), (3) live/conduct oneself (Gen 17:1), (4) disappear (Gen 15:2). 'Walk with God' = lifestyle of faith.

keyPassages.significance: Enoch walked with God - intimate relationship.
Walk humbly with your God.

entries.theologicalNote: Walking is the Jewish metaphor for living (halakah = Jewish law comes from this). One 'walks' in God's ways. Walking implies steady progress in a direction over time.

entries.etymology: Piel form intensifies the action - to give authoritative orders. Implies authority over the one commanded.
entries.otUsage: Occurs 496 times. Used for: (1) divine commands (Gen 2:16), (2) royal orders (1 Sam 18:22), (3) instructions (Gen 50:16), (4) commissioning (Josh 1:9). Most often God as subject.

keyPassages.significance: YHWH God commanded the man - first divine command.

keyPassages.hebrew: וְהָיוּ הַדְּבָרִים הָאֵלֶּה אֲשֶׁר אָנֹכִי מְצַוְּךָ הַיּוֹם עַל־לְבָבֶךָ
keyPassages.significance: These words which I am commanding you today shall be on your heart.

entries.theologicalNote: God's commands are expressions of His will for human flourishing. To be commanded is to be in relationship with the Commander. Divine commands reveal divine care.

entries.etymology: Related to 'goad' - like prodding an ox. Learning is directed, disciplined acquisition through practice.
entries.otUsage: Occurs 87 times. Qal = learn (Deut 5:1), Piel = teach (Deut 4:1). Used for: (1) learning Torah (Deut 31:12), (2) acquiring skills (Isa 2:4), (3) habituating (Jer 10:2).

keyPassages.significance: Learn them and be careful to observe them.
They shall learn war no more - eschatological peace.

entries.theologicalNote: Torah study is the premier Jewish value. Learning leads to doing. Teaching Torah to children is a sacred duty (Deut 6:7). The goal is transformed living, not mere knowledge.

entries.etymology: To cut in, engrave, then write. Writing preserves and transmits across time and space.
entries.otUsage: Occurs 225 times. Used for: (1) divine writing (Exod 31:18), (2) recording (Exod 17:14), (3) legal documents (Deut 24:1), (4) letters (2 Sam 11:14), (5) books (Isa 30:8).

keyPassages.significance: Written by the finger of God - tablets of testimony.
Write them on the doorposts of your house.

entries.theologicalNote: God chose to write - tablets, books of life. Scripture is written revelation. Writing Torah on hearts (Jer 31:33) internalizes what was external.

entries.etymology: To call out, cry, summon. Reading was done aloud; 'read' and 'call' are the same word.
entries.otUsage: Occurs 739 times. Means: (1) call/name (Gen 1:5), (2) summon (Gen 12:18), (3) proclaim (Isa 40:6), (4) read aloud (Jer 36:6), (5) invoke God (Gen 4:26). Public communication.

keyPassages.significance: They read from the book of the Torah distinctly.

keyPassages.hebrew: דִּרְשׁוּ יְהוָה בְּהִמָּצְאוֹ קְרָאֻהוּ בִּהְיוֹתוֹ קָרוֹב
keyPassages.significance: Seek YHWH while He may be found; call upon Him while He is near.

entries.theologicalNote: Calling on God's name is worship and prayer. Reading Scripture aloud is proclamation. God calls people by name - an intimate summons to relationship and mission.

relatedWords.relationship: Convocation, reading - that which is called

entries.etymology: Participle of שָׁפַט (shaphat) - one who judges. The judge both decides cases and governs/delivers.
entries.otUsage: Occurs 68 times as noun. Refers to: (1) judicial officials (Deut 16:18), (2) tribal deliverers (Judg 2:16), (3) God as Judge (Gen 18:25), (4) leaders (Isa 1:26). Judges = leaders before kings.

keyPassages.hebrew: וַיָּקֶם יְהוָה שֹׁפְטִים וַיּוֹשִׁיעוּם מִיַּד שֹׁסֵיהֶם
keyPassages.significance: YHWH raised up judges who saved them from plunderers.
God is a righteous Judge.

entries.theologicalNote: Biblical judges combined roles: legal decisions, military leadership, spiritual guidance. The period of Judges shows cycles of sin, oppression, crying out, and deliverance. God is the ultimate Judge.

entries.etymology: One who repeats, affirms, testifies. Related to עוּד (ud) - return, repeat. A witness confirms by repeating what was seen or agreed.
entries.otUsage: Occurs 69 times. Used for: (1) legal witness (Deut 17:6), (2) false witness (Exod 20:16), (3) memorial object (Gen 31:52), (4) God as witness (1 Sam 12:5). Two witnesses required for conviction.

keyPassages.hebrew: עַל־פִּי שְׁנֵי עֵדִים אוֹ עַל־פִּי שְׁלֹשָׁה־עֵדִים יָקוּם דָּבָר
keyPassages.significance: A matter is established by two or three witnesses.
You are My witnesses, declares YHWH.

entries.theologicalNote: Israel is God's witness to the nations. False witness destroys community and is forbidden in the Decalogue. Martyrdom comes from Greek 'witness' - some witnesses die for their testimony.

entries.etymology: Concrete meaning is 'miss the target' (Judg 20:16). Sin is missing God's intended standard, falling short of the goal.
entries.otUsage: Occurs 238 times as verb. Means: (1) sin against God (Gen 20:6), (2) sin against people (Gen 42:22), (3) miss target (Judg 20:16), (4) forfeit/lose (Hab 2:10). Most common sin word.

keyPassages.significance: Sin crouches at the door - personified threat.
Against You, You only, have I sinned.

entries.theologicalNote: Sin is fundamentally missing God's mark. It's relational before legal - sin against God. The sin offering (chattat) addresses this failure. All sin is ultimately against God (Ps 51:4).

entries.etymology: From עָוָה (avah) - to bend, twist, distort. Iniquity is crookedness, perversion of what is straight.
entries.otUsage: Occurs 231 times. Denotes: (1) twisted act (Gen 19:15), (2) guilt incurred (Lev 5:1), (3) punishment deserved (Gen 4:13). Often translated all three ways. Emphasizes distortion.

keyPassages.hebrew: וַיהוָה הִפְגִּיעַ בּוֹ אֵת עֲוֹן כֻּלָּנוּ
keyPassages.significance: YHWH laid on Him the iniquity of us all.
Forgiving iniquity, transgression, and sin.

entries.theologicalNote: Avon captures sin's distorting nature - bending what God made straight. It includes guilt and consequences. Only God can bear/carry (nasa) iniquity. The Suffering Servant bears our avon.

entries.etymology: From פָּשַׁע (pasha) - to rebel, break away. Pesha is willful violation, breaking covenant or relationship.
entries.otUsage: Occurs 93 times. Means: (1) political rebellion (1 Kings 12:19), (2) covenant violation (Amos 2:4), (3) crime (Prov 28:24). Emphasizes willful defiance, not mere failure.

keyPassages.significance: He was wounded for our transgressions.
For three transgressions of Israel...

entries.theologicalNote: Pesha is the most severe sin term - deliberate rebellion against God's authority. Not accidental but willful. Nations and individuals commit pesha. Emphasizes broken relationship.

entries.etymology: From רָעַע (ra'a) - to be bad, evil. Covers both moral evil and physical harm/calamity.
entries.otUsage: Occurs 663 times. Means: (1) moral evil (Gen 3:5), (2) harmful (Gen 26:29), (3) displeasing (Gen 28:8), (4) ugly (Gen 41:3), (5) calamity (Amos 3:6). Broad negative term.

keyPassages.significance: You will be like God, knowing good and evil.
Making peace and creating calamity.

entries.theologicalNote: Good and evil (tov va-ra) encompasses all of moral experience. The tree of knowledge gave discernment of good and evil. Evil opposes God's good purposes. God can use 'ra' (calamity) for judgment.

entries.etymology: Possibly from verb meaning 'be agitated, disturbed.' The wicked disturb society and are themselves disturbed.
entries.otUsage: Occurs 263 times (82 as noun). Opposite of צַדִּיק (tsaddiq - righteous). The wicked: (1) oppress poor (Ps 10:2), (2) perish (Ps 1:6), (3) have no peace (Isa 48:22).

keyPassages.significance: But the way of the wicked will perish.
Do I have pleasure in the death of the wicked?

entries.theologicalNote: Wisdom literature contrasts the righteous and wicked as two ways of life. The wicked may prosper briefly but face judgment. God desires their repentance, not death (Ezek 18:23).

entries.etymology: Ritual impurity that bars from sacred presence. Not primarily moral but ceremonial - contact with death, disease, bodily discharge.
entries.otUsage: Occurs 88 times. Sources: (1) death/corpse (Num 19:11), (2) disease (Lev 13:3), (3) bodily functions (Lev 15), (4) unclean foods (Lev 11), (5) moral defilement (Lev 18:24). Excludes from temple.

keyPassages.significance: Do not defile yourselves with any swarming thing.

keyPassages.hebrew: אוֹי־לִי כִי־נִדְמֵיתִי כִּי אִישׁ טְמֵא־שְׂפָתַיִם אָנֹכִי
keyPassages.significance: Woe is me! For I am a man of unclean lips.

entries.theologicalNote: Ritual purity teaches holiness - separation from death and disorder. Impurity is contagious; holiness must be protected. The clean/unclean system symbolically teaches about sin and holiness.

entries.etymology: State of ritual purity allowing approach to sacred things. Opposite of tame (unclean).
entries.otUsage: Occurs 96 times. Means: (1) ritually pure (Lev 13:13), (2) morally pure (Ps 51:10), (3) free from impurity (Lev 16:30). Achieved through time, water, and sacrifice.

keyPassages.significance: Create in me a clean heart, O God.

keyPassages.hebrew: כִּי־בַיּוֹם הַזֶּה יְכַפֵּר עֲלֵיכֶם לְטַהֵר אֶתְכֶם
keyPassages.significance: On this day atonement is made for you to cleanse you.

entries.theologicalNote: Cleanness allows access to God. Levitical rituals provide purification. David prays for inner cleansing (Ps 51). The blood cleanses from sin. Pure in heart see God (Matt 5:8).

entries.etymology: To execute justice against wrongdoing. Not personal revenge but vindication of right order.
entries.otUsage: Occurs 35 times. Used for: (1) divine vengeance (Deut 32:35), (2) human justice (Judg 16:28), (3) blood vengeance (Num 35:19). Primarily God's prerogative.

keyPassages.significance: Vengeance is Mine, and recompense.
A jealous and avenging God is YHWH.

entries.theologicalNote: Vengeance belongs to God - humans must not take it (Lev 19:18). Divine vengeance is righteous response to injustice. It vindicates the oppressed and punishes oppressors. Different from human revenge.

entries.etymology: To exercise the functions of a judge - decide cases, govern, deliver. Broad ruling authority.
entries.otUsage: Occurs 204 times. Means: (1) decide cases (Exod 18:16), (2) govern (1 Sam 7:15), (3) deliver/vindicate (Ps 26:1), (4) condemn (Ps 109:7). Combined roles in Judges period.

keyPassages.significance: Shall not the Judge of all the earth do what is just?
Arise, O God, judge the earth!

entries.theologicalNote: God is the ultimate Judge - Abraham appeals to His justice. Human judges represent divine justice. Right judgment protects the vulnerable. Corruption of judgment is condemned by prophets.

entries.etymology: Related to Akkadian 'to judge.' Legal terminology for case or verdict. Also verb 'to judge.'
entries.otUsage: Occurs 24 times as noun. Means: (1) legal case (Prov 31:8), (2) judgment (Deut 17:8), (3) rights (Jer 5:28). Related to mishpat but more focused on specific cases.

keyPassages.significance: Open your mouth for the mute, for the rights of all the destitute.
They do not judge the case of the orphan.

entries.theologicalNote: Din often refers to the legal case of the vulnerable - orphans, widows, poor. True religion includes defending their din. Neglecting din is prophetic indictment.

entries.etymology: Literally 'nose' - anger makes the nose snort and flare. Physical expression gives name to emotion.
entries.otUsage: Occurs 277 times. Means: (1) nose (Gen 2:7), (2) anger (Gen 27:45), (3) face (Gen 3:19). 'Slow to anger' = 'long of nostrils' (patient breathing). Divine and human anger.

keyPassages.hebrew: יְהוָה יְהוָה אֵל רַחוּם וְחַנּוּן אֶרֶךְ אַפַּיִם
keyPassages.significance: YHWH, compassionate, gracious, slow to anger.
His anger is for a moment; His favor is for a lifetime.

entries.theologicalNote: God's anger is real but controlled - He is 'slow to anger.' Divine anger responds to sin but is not capricious. God's anger passes; His love endures. Humans warned against uncontrolled anger.

entries.etymology: To be hot, kindled. Anger as burning heat - face flushes, temperature rises. Passionate emotional reaction.
entries.otUsage: Occurs 93 times. Used for: (1) divine anger (Exod 4:14), (2) human anger (Gen 4:5), (3) with 'aph' - nose burns hot (Gen 44:18). Often in 'it burned to him' = he became angry.

keyPassages.significance: Cain was very angry - first recorded human anger.
Now leave Me alone that My anger may burn against them.

entries.theologicalNote: Anger is portrayed as burning fire that must be controlled. Cain's anger led to murder - warning about unchecked passion. God's anger burns against sin but can be turned away by intercession.

entries.etymology: From קָצַף (qatsaph) - to be wrathful. Intense anger, especially divine judgment against sin.
entries.otUsage: Occurs 29 times. Primarily divine wrath (Num 1:53), sometimes human anger (Esth 1:18). Related to breaking off in rage. Leads to punishment and judgment.

keyPassages.significance: So there will be no wrath on the congregation of Israel.
These seventy years You have been indignant.

entries.theologicalNote: Divine wrath is not arbitrary but responds to covenant violation. The Levites' service prevents qetseph. Wrath can be averted through proper worship and intercession. It expresses God's holiness.

entries.etymology: To impose a penalty, especially monetary. Legal punishment for wrongdoing.
entries.otUsage: Occurs 9 times. Used for: (1) monetary fines (Exod 21:22), (2) divine punishment (Amos 2:8), (3) discipline (Prov 17:26). Often financial penalty, sometimes broader punishment.

keyPassages.hebrew: וְנָתַן בִּפְלִלִים כַּאֲשֶׁר יָשִׁית עָלָיו בַּעַל הָאִשָּׁה
keyPassages.significance: He shall pay as the judges determine - legal punishment.
To punish the righteous is also not good.

entries.theologicalNote: Punishment maintains social order and justice. Punishing the innocent is condemned. God's punishment is restorative not merely retributive. Consequences follow wrongdoing.

entries.etymology: Universal Semitic root for death. The fundamental end of physical life and its consequences.
entries.otUsage: Occurs 835 times. Means: (1) physical death (Gen 3:4), (2) deserve death (Gen 20:7), (3) kill (Gen 37:18), (4) death as punishment (Lev 20:2). 'Dying you shall die' = emphatic certainty.

keyPassages.significance: Dying you shall die - consequence of sin.
I have no pleasure in the death of anyone.

entries.theologicalNote: Death entered through sin (Gen 3). 'The soul that sins shall die' (Ezek 18:4). Yet God does not delight in death but desires repentance. Death is the 'last enemy' to be conquered.

entries.etymology: Uncertain - possibly from 'to ask' (inquire of dead) or 'hollow.' The place of the dead beneath the earth.
entries.otUsage: Occurs 65 times. Refers to: (1) the grave (Gen 37:35), (2) the underworld (Isa 14:9), (3) state of death (Ps 6:5). All dead go there - shadowy existence, cut off from God's praise.

keyPassages.significance: You will not abandon my soul to Sheol.
Sheol beneath is stirred up to meet you.

entries.theologicalNote: Sheol represents death's power and realm. There is no praise of God there (Ps 6:5). Yet even Sheol is not beyond God's reach (Ps 139:8). Hope of resurrection transcends Sheol.

entries.etymology: Root meaning is 'be wide, spacious' - deliverance brings room to breathe after oppression's constriction.
entries.otUsage: Occurs 205 times. Used for: (1) military victory (Judg 2:16), (2) rescue from danger (Ps 22:21), (3) divine salvation (Isa 45:22). Joshua and Jesus from this root.

keyPassages.significance: Turn to Me and be saved, all ends of the earth.
Salvation belongs to YHWH.

entries.theologicalNote: Salvation is God's signature work - He alone saves. Human deliverers (judges, kings) are instruments. Names Yeshua/Joshua/Jesus mean 'YHWH saves.' Salvation is comprehensive - physical, spiritual, national.

entries.etymology: To act as kinsman-redeemer - reclaim family property, marry widow, avenge blood. Family obligation.
entries.otUsage: Occurs 104 times. Used for: (1) property redemption (Lev 25:25), (2) levirate marriage (Ruth 3:13), (3) blood vengeance (Num 35:19), (4) divine redemption (Exod 6:6). Family/covenant term.

keyPassages.hebrew: וּפָרַשְׂתָּ כְנָפֶךָ עַל־אֲמָתְךָ כִּי גֹאֵל אָתָּה
keyPassages.significance: Spread your wings over your servant, for you are a redeemer.
Return to Me, for I have redeemed you.

entries.theologicalNote: Go'el expresses family obligation - God is Israel's kinsman-redeemer. Boaz pictures the go'el. Redemption is personal, relational, costly. The Redeemer pays the price and claims His own.

entries.etymology: To ransom by payment, buy back. Commercial transaction - paying a price to secure release.
entries.otUsage: Occurs 60 times. Used for: (1) redeeming firstborn (Exod 13:13), (2) releasing slaves (Deut 7:8), (3) ransoming from death (Ps 49:7). Emphasizes price paid.

keyPassages.significance: He ransomed you from the house of slavery.

keyPassages.hebrew: אָח לֹא פָדֹה יִפְדֶּה אִישׁ... וְיֵחַת פִּדְיוֹן נַפְשָׁם
keyPassages.significance: No man can by any means redeem his brother... the ransom of his soul is costly.

entries.theologicalNote: Padah emphasizes costly payment. God paid to redeem Israel from slavery. The price of a soul is beyond human ability - only God can pay it. Ransom language underlies atonement theology.

entries.etymology: To pull out, snatch away, rescue. Urgent action - snatching from imminent danger.
entries.otUsage: Occurs 213 times. Means: (1) rescue from danger (Gen 32:11), (2) snatch from predator (1 Sam 17:35), (3) deliver from enemy (Exod 3:8). Emphasizes urgency and power.

keyPassages.significance: I have come down to deliver them from the hand of Egypt.
Call upon Me in the day of trouble; I will deliver you.

entries.theologicalNote: Natsal often pictures snatching from the jaws of danger. David snatched sheep from lions. God snatches Israel from Egypt. Prayer in distress brings divine rescue.

entries.etymology: To slip away, escape. Originally 'be smooth, slippery' - sliding out of danger's grasp.
entries.otUsage: Occurs 94 times. Means: (1) escape (Gen 19:17), (2) rescue (1 Sam 19:10), (3) deliver (Ps 41:1). Often with urgency - flee for your life!

keyPassages.significance: Escape for your life! - urgent command to Lot.
Our soul escaped like a bird from the snare of fowlers.

entries.theologicalNote: Malat pictures narrow escape - like a bird slipping from a trap. The image is of breaking free from what would capture or destroy. God enables His people to escape.

entries.etymology: To surround, protect, aid. Help that strengthens and supports in time of need.
entries.otUsage: Occurs 82 times. Used for: (1) military aid (Josh 10:4), (2) divine help (Ps 121:1-2), (3) mutual support (Gen 2:18). Names like Eliezer, Azariah from this root.

keyPassages.hebrew: מֵאַיִן יָבֹא עֶזְרִי עֶזְרִי מֵעִם יְהוָה
keyPassages.significance: Where does my help come from? My help is from YHWH.
I will make him a helper corresponding to him.

entries.theologicalNote: God is the ultimate Helper - not to replace our effort but to strengthen it. Eve as 'ezer' is not subordinate - the same word describes God. Help implies relationship and collaboration.

entries.etymology: Possibly 'cover over' or 'wipe clean.' The atonement covers sin or cleanses the sinner, restoring relationship.
entries.otUsage: Occurs 102 times. Central to Levitical system: (1) sacrificial atonement (Lev 1:4), (2) ransom price (Exod 30:12), (3) appease anger (Gen 32:20). Yom Kippur = Day of Atonement.

keyPassages.significance: It is the blood that makes atonement for the soul.
On this day atonement shall be made for you.

entries.theologicalNote: Atonement addresses the fundamental problem of sin before a holy God. Blood makes atonement because 'the life is in the blood.' The Day of Atonement provided annual cleansing. Christ's blood provides eternal atonement.

entries.etymology: Used exclusively of God's forgiveness - only God can truly salach. Divine prerogative.
entries.otUsage: Occurs 46 times. Always God as subject - humans cannot salach. Used for: (1) responding to confession (1 Kings 8:30), (2) pardoning rebellion (Num 14:19), (3) divine nature (Ps 86:5).

keyPassages.significance: You, Lord, are good and forgiving.
For I will forgive their iniquity.

entries.theologicalNote: Only God forgives sin absolutely - salach is His alone. He forgives freely and completely when people repent. The new covenant promises universal knowledge of God because He forgives.

entries.etymology: To lift up, bear, carry. Forgiveness is 'lifting away' the burden of sin.
entries.otUsage: Occurs 659 times. Means: (1) lift/carry (Gen 7:17), (2) bear (Isa 53:4), (3) forgive (Gen 50:17), (4) take away (Lev 10:17). 'Lift up the face' = show favor.

keyPassages.significance: Forgiving iniquity, transgression, and sin.
Blessed is he whose transgression is lifted/forgiven.

entries.theologicalNote: Nasa pictures sin as a burden that is lifted off and carried away. The Suffering Servant 'bears' our iniquities (Isa 53:4). Sin's weight is removed by divine grace.

entries.etymology: To mend, repair, heal. Restoration to wholeness - physical, emotional, spiritual, national.
entries.otUsage: Occurs 67 times. Used for: (1) physical healing (Gen 20:17), (2) water purification (2 Kings 2:21), (3) national restoration (Isa 6:10), (4) emotional healing (Ps 147:3). Comprehensive restoration.

keyPassages.significance: I am YHWH your healer (Jehovah Rapha).
By His stripes we are healed.

entries.theologicalNote: God is the Healer - physical and spiritual. Sin is sickness requiring divine healing. The Suffering Servant's wounds bring healing. Healing is often connected with forgiveness (Ps 103:3).

entries.etymology: Basic verb for living, being alive. Includes preservation and restoration of life.
entries.otUsage: Occurs 283 times. Means: (1) live (Gen 3:22), (2) remain alive (Gen 12:12), (3) revive (1 Kings 17:22), (4) give life (Deut 32:39). God gives and sustains life.

keyPassages.significance: Life and death... choose life!

keyPassages.hebrew: הִנֵּה אֲנִי מֵבִיא בָכֶם רוּחַ וִחְיִיתֶם
keyPassages.significance: I will cause breath to enter you, and you shall live.

entries.theologicalNote: Life is God's gift - He alone gives and takes it. The choice is life or death, blessing or curse. Ezekiel's dry bones shows God can revive what is utterly dead. Eternal life is the ultimate goal.

entries.etymology: Basic meaning is physical turning - turning back, returning. Spiritually: turning from sin to God.
entries.otUsage: Occurs 1,066 times - very common. Means: (1) return physically (Gen 3:19), (2) repent (1 Kings 8:48), (3) restore (Ruth 4:15), (4) do again (Gen 26:18). Key prophetic call.

keyPassages.significance: Come, let us return to YHWH.
Return to Me with all your heart.

entries.theologicalNote: Repentance is turning - from sin to God, from death to life. The prophets constantly call: 'Shuv!' Return! It's not merely feeling sorry but changing direction. God also 'turns' - restoring His people.

entries.etymology: To breathe deeply, sigh. The sigh of relief or grief. Both comfort given and change of mind.
entries.otUsage: Occurs 108 times. Means: (1) comfort mourner (Gen 37:35), (2) God relents (Exod 32:14), (3) repent (Jer 8:6), (4) avenge (Isa 1:24). Niphal often = relent/repent.

keyPassages.significance: Comfort, comfort My people.
YHWH relented from the harm He had planned.

entries.theologicalNote: God comforts His people after judgment. Isaiah 40 begins Israel's comfort. God also 'repents' (relents) - not changing His character but responding to changed circumstances. Comfort comes after sorrow.

entries.etymology: To bend down, show favor. The superior's condescension to help the inferior - unmerited kindness.
entries.otUsage: Occurs 77 times. Used for: (1) divine grace (Exod 33:19), (2) human favor (Gen 33:5), (3) plea for mercy (Ps 4:1). Root of chen (grace), channun (gracious), Hannah.

keyPassages.significance: I will be gracious to whom I will be gracious.
YHWH make His face shine on you and be gracious to you.

entries.theologicalNote: Grace is God's free, unmerited favor. The priestly blessing invokes it. God's sovereignty in grace - He chooses whom to favor. Human pleas for grace acknowledge complete dependence.

entries.etymology: Related to רֶחֶם (rechem) - womb. Compassion like a mother's love for the child of her womb.
entries.otUsage: Occurs 47 times. Means: (1) show compassion (Exod 33:19), (2) love tenderly (Ps 103:13), (3) find mercy (Hos 2:23). Deeply emotional, visceral love.

keyPassages.hebrew: כְּרַחֵם אָב עַל־בָּנִים רִחַם יְהוָה עַל־יְרֵאָיו
keyPassages.significance: As a father has compassion on his children, so YHWH has compassion.
Can a woman forget her nursing child... show no compassion for the son of her womb?

entries.theologicalNote: Rachamim (pl.) is visceral, womb-love. God's compassion surpasses even a mother's. This is not cold duty but deep emotional identification. God suffers with His suffering people.

entries.etymology: Plural form of חַי (chai) - living. Always plural in Hebrew, suggesting life's fullness and complexity.
entries.otUsage: Occurs 275 times. Means: (1) physical life (Gen 2:7), (2) lifetime (Gen 23:1), (3) vigorous life (Deut 30:15), (4) eternal life (Dan 12:2). Opposite of mavet (death).

keyPassages.significance: I have set before you life and death.
She (wisdom) is a tree of life to those who lay hold of her.

entries.theologicalNote: Life is God's gift and goal. The 'tree of life' in Eden represents eternal life. The covenant offers life vs. death. Wisdom leads to life. The 'Book of Life' records those destined for eternal life.

entries.etymology: Feminine noun from יָשַׁע (yasha). The state or experience of having been saved/delivered.
entries.otUsage: Occurs 78 times. Refers to: (1) military victory (1 Sam 14:45), (2) divine rescue (Exod 14:13), (3) comprehensive wellbeing (Ps 27:1). Name Yeshua/Jesus derives from this.

keyPassages.significance: Stand still and see the salvation of YHWH.
YHWH is my light and my salvation - whom shall I fear?

entries.theologicalNote: Salvation encompasses deliverance from all threats - enemies, sin, death. It is wholly God's work to give and ours to receive. The name Jesus (Yeshua) means 'YHWH saves' - God's salvation incarnate.

entries.etymology: From חָכַם (chakam) - be wise. Practical skill in living applied to all of life - from craftsmanship to moral discernment.
entries.otUsage: Occurs 153 times. Means: (1) skill/craftsmanship (Exod 28:3), (2) practical wisdom (Prov 4:5), (3) personified wisdom (Prov 8), (4) divine wisdom (Job 12:13). Central to wisdom literature.

keyPassages.significance: Wisdom is the principal thing; get wisdom.
The fear of YHWH is the beginning of wisdom.

entries.theologicalNote: Wisdom begins with fearing God. It is both practical skill and moral insight. Personified wisdom in Proverbs 8 is present at creation. Christ is 'the wisdom of God' (1 Cor 1:24).

entries.etymology: From בִּין (bin) - discern, understand. The ability to distinguish between things, to perceive meaning.
entries.otUsage: Occurs 38 times. Means: (1) discernment (Prov 2:3), (2) understanding (Job 28:12), (3) insight (Dan 1:20). Often paired with chokmah (wisdom). Intelligence applied to discernment.

keyPassages.significance: To understand wisdom and discipline... call out for understanding.
Get wisdom, get understanding.

entries.theologicalNote: Understanding is the capacity to perceive underlying meanings and distinctions. It works with wisdom to produce right living. God's understanding is infinite; humans must seek it diligently.

entries.etymology: From יָדַע (yada) - know. Knowledge in Hebrew is experiential and relational, not merely intellectual.
entries.otUsage: Occurs 93 times. Means: (1) knowledge (Gen 2:9), (2) awareness (Exod 31:3), (3) skill (2 Chr 1:10). 'Knowledge of God' is intimate relationship. Tree of knowledge (Gen 2-3) is central.

keyPassages.significance: My people are destroyed for lack of knowledge.
The fear of YHWH is the beginning of knowledge.

entries.theologicalNote: Knowledge of God is the highest knowledge - personal, experiential, covenantal. It begins with reverence. Lack of knowledge destroys. The new covenant promise is universal knowledge of God.

entries.etymology: To be circumspect, act wisely. The wisdom that leads to success through careful consideration.
entries.otUsage: Occurs 63 times. Means: (1) act wisely (1 Sam 18:14), (2) have insight (Ps 41:1), (3) prosper (Josh 1:8), (4) instruct (Neh 9:20). Wisdom applied to practical success.

keyPassages.significance: Then you will prosper and have good success.
I will instruct you and teach you the way you should go.

entries.theologicalNote: True insight comes from meditation on Torah (Josh 1:8). God promises to give sakal to His people. It results in success/prosperity when applied. The 'maskil' psalms teach this kind of wisdom.

entries.etymology: From עָרַם (aram) - be cunning. Can be positive (prudent) or negative (crafty), depending on context.
entries.otUsage: Occurs 11 times. Means: (1) prudent (Prov 12:16), (2) shrewd (Prov 14:8), (3) crafty (Gen 3:1 - the serpent). Same word describes wisdom's caution and the serpent's cunning.

keyPassages.significance: The wisdom of the prudent is to understand his way.

keyPassages.hebrew: וְהַנָּחָשׁ הָיָה עָרוּם מִכֹּל חַיַּת הַשָּׂדֶה
keyPassages.significance: The serpent was more crafty than any beast of the field.

entries.theologicalNote: Prudence is wisdom's caution - careful consideration before acting. The same quality can be misused (the serpent). Context determines whether arum is praiseworthy or blameworthy.

entries.etymology: From פָּתָה (patah) - be open, entice. The simple are open - susceptible to influence, easily deceived.
entries.otUsage: Occurs 19 times. Refers to those: (1) inexperienced (Prov 1:4), (2) easily led astray (Prov 7:7), (3) lacking judgment (Prov 9:4). Not yet wicked but vulnerable to becoming so.

keyPassages.significance: To give prudence to the simple - Proverbs' purpose.
Whoever is simple, let him turn in here - Wisdom's invitation.

entries.theologicalNote: The simple are at a crossroads - they can become wise or foolish. Proverbs is written especially for them. Wisdom calls to the simple, but so does Folly. They must choose their teacher.

entries.etymology: Related to thickness, fatness - thick-headed, mentally dull. Moral rather than intellectual failure.
entries.otUsage: Occurs 26 times. Describes: (1) those who despise wisdom (Prov 1:7), (2) morally perverse (Prov 10:8), (3) quick-tempered (Prov 12:16). More culpable than the simple (peti).

keyPassages.significance: Fools despise wisdom and discipline.
The way of a fool is right in his own eyes.
