entries.theologicalNote: The evil is morally thick - they won't listen. They think themselves wise but despise correction. Unlike the simple, they have made their choice against wisdom. Still, Proverbs warns them.

entries.etymology: From כָּסַל (kasal) - be sluggish, foolish. Stupidity as moral/spiritual condition, not mental incapacity.
entries.otUsage: Occurs 70 times. The kesil: (1) hates knowledge (Prov 1:22), (2) trusts own heart (Prov 28:26), (3) returns to folly (Prov 26:11). The most common 'fool' word in Proverbs.

keyPassages.significance: And fools hate knowledge.

keyPassages.hebrew: כְּכֶלֶב שָׁב עַל־קֵאוֹ כְּסִיל שׁוֹנֶה בְאִוַּלְתּוֹ
keyPassages.significance: Like a dog returns to its vomit, so a fool repeats his folly.

entries.theologicalNote: The kesil is stubbornly stupid - they hate correction and repeat mistakes. Their foolishness is moral, not intellectual. They are set in their ways. Proverbs exposes their self-destruction.

entries.etymology: From נָבֵל (navel) - wither, be senseless. A moral failure that impacts community - churlish, godless.
entries.otUsage: Occurs 18 times. The naval: (1) denies God (Ps 14:1), (2) is churlish (1 Sam 25:25 - Nabal), (3) speaks folly (Isa 32:6). Most severe fool - moral and spiritual bankruptcy.

keyPassages.significance: The fool says in his heart, 'There is no God.'

keyPassages.hebrew: כִּי כִשְׁמוֹ כֶּן־הוּא נָבָל שְׁמוֹ וּנְבָלָה עִמּוֹ
keyPassages.significance: As his name is, so is he - Nabal is his name, and folly is with him.

entries.theologicalNote: The naval is godless - practical atheism that impacts ethics. Nabal's story illustrates this fool perfectly. The naval's denial of God leads to harm of others. This is the worst form of folly.

entries.etymology: From יָסַר (yasar) - to discipline, correct. Instruction that includes correction - learning through discipline.
entries.otUsage: Occurs 50 times. Means: (1) parental discipline (Prov 1:8), (2) moral instruction (Prov 4:1), (3) correction/chastening (Prov 3:11). Central concept in Proverbs. Love requires discipline.

keyPassages.significance: Hear, my son, your father's discipline.
My son, do not despise YHWH's discipline.

entries.theologicalNote: True learning includes correction - painful but necessary. God disciplines those He loves (Prov 3:12). Rejecting discipline leads to death. The wise receive it; fools despise it.

entries.etymology: From יָכַח (yakach) - argue, prove, correct. The verbal correction that accompanies discipline.
entries.otUsage: Occurs 28 times. Means: (1) reproof (Prov 1:23), (2) rebuke (Prov 6:23), (3) argument/reasoning (Hab 2:1). Verbal correction that opens eyes to error. Sign of love, not hatred.

keyPassages.significance: The reproofs of discipline are the way of life.
He who heeds reproof is honored.

entries.theologicalNote: Rebuke is a gift - the faithful wounds of a friend. Receiving correction leads to life and honor. The wise love those who rebuke them; fools hate correction. It separates the wise from fools.

entries.etymology: To give counsel, deliberate, resolve. Thoughtful advice leading to wise decisions.
entries.otUsage: Occurs 80 times. Means: (1) give counsel (2 Sam 16:23), (2) take counsel (Ps 2:2), (3) purpose/plan (Isa 14:24). Good counsel comes from the wise; God is the ultimate Counselor.

keyPassages.significance: In abundance of counselors there is safety.
Wonderful Counselor, Mighty God...

entries.theologicalNote: Multiple counselors provide safety - no one is wise alone. God's counsel stands forever (Ps 33:11). The Messiah is 'Wonderful Counselor' - perfect wisdom. Seek counsel before acting.

entries.etymology: To ask, inquire, request. Seeking information, guidance, or petition. Saul and Samuel from this root.
entries.otUsage: Occurs 176 times. Means: (1) ask question (Gen 32:29), (2) request (1 Sam 1:20), (3) inquire of God (1 Sam 28:6), (4) borrow (Exod 3:22). Asking acknowledges need and seeks help.

keyPassages.significance: Ask what I shall give you - God to Solomon.

keyPassages.hebrew: אִם־לְאֶחָד מִכֶּם חָסֵר חָכְמָה יִשְׁאַל מֵאֱלֹהִים
keyPassages.significance: If any lacks wisdom, let him ask of God - OT principle.

entries.theologicalNote: Asking reveals humility - we don't have all answers. Solomon's wisdom began by asking. God invites us to ask (Matt 7:7). Not asking often leads to failure. Ask for wisdom first.

entries.etymology: To examine, test. Like testing metal for purity - probing to discover true quality.
entries.otUsage: Occurs 29 times. God tests: (1) hearts (Jer 11:20), (2) minds (Ps 7:9), (3) people (Ps 66:10). Humans should test words (Job 12:11). Different from nasah (testing by trial).

keyPassages.significance: Examine me, YHWH, and test me.

keyPassages.hebrew: אֲנִי יְהוָה חֹקֵר לֵב בֹּחֵן כְּלָיוֹת
keyPassages.significance: I YHWH search the heart and test the mind.

entries.theologicalNote: God tests to reveal what's truly inside. Testing refines like fire purifies metal. We should invite God's testing - it leads to growth. Test words and teachings before accepting.

entries.etymology: To test by experience or trial. Testing through putting to the proof in circumstances.
entries.otUsage: Occurs 36 times. Used for: (1) God testing people (Gen 22:1), (2) people testing God (Exod 17:2), (3) trying something new (1 Sam 17:39). Abraham tested supremely. Testing at Massah.

keyPassages.significance: God tested Abraham - the binding of Isaac.
Why do you test YHWH? - at Massah.

entries.theologicalNote: God tests faith to prove it genuine - Abraham's test revealed his fear of God. Israel wrongly tested God by doubting His presence. We are tested; we should not test God.

entries.etymology: Fundamental verb of knowing - experiential, intimate, personal. Not mere information but relationship.
entries.otUsage: Occurs 947 times - extremely common. Means: (1) know facts (Gen 4:1), (2) know persons (Jer 1:5), (3) experience (Isa 53:3), (4) marital intimacy (Gen 4:1). 'Know YHWH' is covenant relationship.

keyPassages.significance: Understand and know Me - highest boast.
You shall know that I am YHWH.

entries.theologicalNote: Knowing God is life's ultimate purpose - not information but intimate relationship. Adam 'knew' Eve (Gen 4:1). God 'knew' Israel before birth (Jer 1:5). To know is to be transformed.

entries.etymology: Related to אֲדָמָה (adamah) - ground, earth. Humanity is from the earth, earthy. Red earth (adam = red).
entries.otUsage: Occurs 562 times. Means: (1) mankind generically (Gen 1:26), (2) a man (Eccl 2:12), (3) Adam the person (Gen 2:19). Emphasizes humanity's earthly origin and mortality.

keyPassages.significance: God created man (adam) in His image.
What is man that You remember him, the son of man that You visit him?

entries.theologicalNote: Adam is both individual and collective - the first man and all humanity. Made from earth but in God's image. 'Son of man' (ben adam) emphasizes human nature. Christ is the 'last Adam.'

entries.etymology: Basic word for individual man as distinct from woman or generically 'a person.' Strength, nobility.
entries.otUsage: Occurs 2,183 times - very common. Means: (1) individual man (Gen 2:24), (2) husband (Gen 3:6), (3) each one (Gen 40:5), (4) soldier (Josh 5:13). Emphasizes individual identity.

keyPassages.significance: Therefore a man shall leave his father and mother.
He has told you, O man, what is good.

entries.theologicalNote: Ish emphasizes individual personhood and responsibility. A man leaves parents to form new family. 'Man of God' (ish elohim) designates prophets. Individual accountability before God.

entries.etymology: From אִישׁ (ish) - man. Woman taken from man, corresponding to him. Word-play: ishah from ish.
entries.otUsage: Occurs 781 times. Means: (1) female (Gen 2:22), (2) wife (Gen 3:8), (3) each one (feminine) (Exod 3:22). First reference explains relationship: 'taken out of man.'

keyPassages.hebrew: לְזֹאת יִקָּרֵא אִשָּׁה כִּי מֵאִישׁ לֻקְחָה־זֹּאת
keyPassages.significance: She shall be called Woman, because she was taken from Man.
A wife of noble character, who can find?

entries.theologicalNote: Woman complements man - taken from his side, corresponding to him. Marriage unites ish and ishah. The 'wife of noble character' (eshet chayil) is wisdom embodied. Equal dignity, distinct roles.

entries.etymology: From בָּנָה (banah) - build. Children 'build' the family. Most common relationship word.
entries.otUsage: Occurs 4,906 times - extremely common. Means: (1) son (Gen 4:25), (2) grandson/descendant (Gen 32:32), (3) member of class (Ps 89:6 - 'sons of God'), (4) characteristic ('son of death' = doomed). Very flexible.

keyPassages.significance: You are My Son; today I have begotten You.
Hear, my son, your father's instruction.

entries.theologicalNote: Sonship implies inheritance and responsibility. Israel is God's 'son' (Exod 4:22). 'Son of man' = human. 'Son of God' = divine relationship. Messianic Psalm 2:7 is quoted of Christ.

entries.etymology: Feminine of בֵּן (ben). Daughter, female descendant, or member of a group.
entries.otUsage: Occurs 587 times. Means: (1) daughter (Gen 24:23), (2) granddaughter (Gen 36:2), (3) women of city ('daughters of Jerusalem'), (4) villages ('daughter' cities). Flexible like ben.

keyPassages.significance: I am dark but lovely, O daughters of Jerusalem.
Say to the daughter of Zion - Jerusalem personified.

entries.theologicalNote: 'Daughter of Zion' personifies Jerusalem/Israel. Daughters represent future generations and inheritance. In patriarchal culture, daughters still had value and protection under law.

entries.etymology: One of the earliest words - baby talk (like 'mama'). Universal across languages. Bond of origin.
entries.otUsage: Occurs 220 times. Means: (1) biological mother (Gen 3:20), (2) grandmother (1 Kings 15:10), (3) metaphorical mother (Judg 5:7). Commandment honors mother equally with father.

keyPassages.significance: Honor your father and your mother.
As one whom his mother comforts, so I will comfort you.

entries.theologicalNote: Mother receives equal honor with father in the Decalogue. God's comfort is compared to a mother's. The matriarchs (Sarah, Rebekah, Rachel, Leah) shape Israel's destiny. Motherhood is honored.

entries.etymology: Basic kinship term. Extended beyond blood to covenant relationships - 'brothers' in treaty.
entries.otUsage: Occurs 629 times. Means: (1) sibling (Gen 4:2), (2) relative (Gen 13:8), (3) fellow countryman (Deut 15:3), (4) ally (Amos 1:9). Cain's question: 'Am I my brother's keeper?'

keyPassages.significance: Am I my brother's keeper?

keyPassages.hebrew: הִנֵּה מַה־טּוֹב וּמַה־נָּעִים שֶׁבֶת אַחִים גַּם־יָחַד
keyPassages.significance: How good and pleasant when brothers dwell together in unity!

entries.theologicalNote: Brotherhood implies mutual responsibility - Cain's question implies its denial. All Israelites are 'brothers.' Unity among brothers is beautiful (Ps 133). Joseph's brothers illustrate both betrayal and reconciliation.

entries.etymology: Feminine of אָח (ach). Female sibling or relative. Extended to close relationships.
entries.otUsage: Occurs 114 times. Means: (1) sibling (Gen 4:22), (2) half-sister (Gen 20:12), (3) beloved (Song 4:9), (4) metaphor (Prov 7:4 - 'sister wisdom'). Tamar's tragedy (2 Sam 13).

keyPassages.significance: You have captured my heart, my sister, my bride.
Say to wisdom, 'You are my sister.'

entries.theologicalNote: Sister as term of endearment in Song of Songs shows intimacy. Wisdom personified as sister indicates close relationship. Sisters in narratives (Miriam, Rachel/Leah, Tamar) play significant roles.

entries.etymology: Related to 'with' - those bound together. People as unified community sharing identity.
entries.otUsage: Occurs 1,868 times. Means: (1) kinfolk (Gen 25:8), (2) nation (Exod 1:9), (3) Israel specifically (Exod 6:7). 'People of God' (am YHWH) is Israel's identity. Often paired with goy.

keyPassages.significance: I will take you to be My people.

keyPassages.hebrew: כִּי עַם קָדוֹשׁ אַתָּה לַיהוָה אֱלֹהֶיךָ
keyPassages.significance: You are a holy people to YHWH your God.

entries.theologicalNote: Am emphasizes unity and kinship. Israel is God's 'am' - His covenant people. Election makes them His special possession. 'Gathered to his people' = ancestral death. People and land are connected.

entries.etymology: Body, community. Originally neutral - any nation. Later, non-Israelite nations (Gentiles).
entries.otUsage: Occurs 567 times. Means: (1) any nation (Gen 10:5), (2) Israel (Gen 12:2), (3) Gentiles/non-Jews (Isa 49:6). Initially applied to Israel too ('great nation'). Later distinguished from am.

keyPassages.significance: I will make you a great nation.
A light to the nations (goyim) - salvation to earth's end.

entries.theologicalNote: Abraham's seed becomes a great goy to bless all goyim. Israel as 'kingdom of priests' mediates to nations. Light to the nations extends salvation universally. Tension between election and universal mission.

entries.etymology: From root related to 'pour out' - those poured out from common source. Extended family/clan unit.
entries.otUsage: Occurs 303 times. Means: (1) family/clan (Gen 10:5), (2) species (Gen 8:19), (3) tribal subdivision (Num 1:2). Between 'house' (bayit) and 'tribe' (shevet) in size.

keyPassages.significance: All families of the earth shall be blessed in you.

keyPassages.hebrew: רַק אֶתְכֶם יָדַעְתִּי מִכֹּל מִשְׁפְּחוֹת הָאֲדָמָה
keyPassages.significance: You only have I known of all the families of the earth.

entries.theologicalNote: All families will be blessed through Abraham - universal scope. Israel is one family among many but specially known (chosen). Family structures society in ancient Israel. Blessing flows through families.

entries.etymology: Rod or staff - symbol of authority. Extended to mean tribe (group under one 'rod'/authority).
entries.otUsage: Occurs 190 times. Means: (1) rod (Prov 13:24), (2) scepter (Gen 49:10), (3) tribe (Num 1:4). Twelve tribes from Jacob's sons. Rod of discipline and royal scepter.

keyPassages.significance: The scepter shall not depart from Judah.
A scepter shall rise from Israel.

entries.theologicalNote: The twelve tribes structure Israel's identity. Judah's tribe holds the scepter/kingship. The messianic scepter comes from Judah. Rod symbolizes both discipline (shepherd) and authority (king).

entries.etymology: From זָרַע (zara) - to sow. Seed for planting; metaphorically, human offspring/descendants.
entries.otUsage: Occurs 229 times. Means: (1) agricultural seed (Gen 1:11), (2) semen (Lev 15:16), (3) offspring (Gen 3:15), (4) descendants (Gen 22:17). Central to covenant promises.

keyPassages.hebrew: וְאֵיבָה אָשִׁית... בֵּין זַרְעֲךָ וּבֵין זַרְעָהּ
keyPassages.significance: Enmity between your seed and her seed - protoevangelium.
I will multiply your seed - Abrahamic promise.

entries.theologicalNote: The 'seed' is the central covenant promise. Abraham's seed inherits the land and blesses nations. The 'seed of the woman' (Gen 3:15) is messianic. Paul reads 'seed' as singular = Christ (Gal 3:16).

entries.etymology: From יָלַד (yalad) - to bear, give birth. The one born - a child from birth to youth.
entries.otUsage: Occurs 89 times. Means: (1) infant (Exod 2:6), (2) young child (Gen 21:8), (3) youth (1 Kings 12:8). Emphasis on being born, the result of birth. 'Child is born' (Isa 9:6).

keyPassages.significance: For to us a child is born - messianic prophecy.
And behold, the child was crying - baby Moses.

entries.theologicalNote: Children are gifts from God (Ps 127:3). The messianic 'child' (yeled) in Isaiah 9 is also 'Mighty God.' Children symbolize the future and covenant continuity. Jesus welcomed children.

entries.etymology: From זָקָן (zaqan) - beard. The bearded one, hence elderly, venerable. Age = authority.
entries.otUsage: Occurs 178 times. Means: (1) old person (Gen 18:11), (2) elder/leader (Exod 3:16), (3) ancient (Job 12:12). Elders lead Israel, cities, and later synagogues. Wisdom comes with age.

keyPassages.hebrew: מִפְּנֵי שֵׂיבָה תָּקוּם וְהָדַרְתָּ פְּנֵי זָקֵן
keyPassages.significance: Rise before the gray-headed and honor the face of an elder.
Go and gather the elders of Israel.

entries.theologicalNote: Elders form Israel's leadership structure - honored for accumulated wisdom. The seventy elders receive Moses' spirit (Num 11). Elder rule continues in synagogue and church. Honor the aged.

entries.etymology: Possibly from 'shake off' - one recently shaken off (weaned). Young person or servant.
entries.otUsage: Occurs 240 times. Means: (1) infant (Exod 2:6), (2) youth (Gen 22:5), (3) servant (Gen 18:7), (4) unmarried man (Judg 17:7). Wide age range. Samuel as na'ar in temple.

keyPassages.significance: The boy Samuel ministered to YHWH.
For I am only a youth - Jeremiah's call.

entries.theologicalNote: God calls the young - Samuel, Jeremiah, David. Youth is no barrier to service. The term also means servant, showing that service is expected of the young. Youth with wisdom is praised.

entries.etymology: From עָבַד (avad) - work, serve. One who serves/works for another. Same root as 'worship.'
entries.otUsage: Occurs 800 times. Means: (1) slave (Exod 21:2), (2) servant (2 Sam 9:2), (3) royal official (2 Kings 22:12), (4) worshiper (Ps 134:1). 'Servant of YHWH' is honorific.

keyPassages.significance: My righteous servant - the Suffering Servant.
Bless YHWH, all servants of YHWH.

entries.theologicalNote: Israel is YHWH's servant (Isa 44:1). Moses, David, prophets are 'servants of YHWH.' The Suffering Servant of Isaiah 53 achieves salvation. Service to God is the highest calling.

entries.etymology: Used exclusively of God's creative activity. Creating something genuinely new. No human subject.
entries.otUsage: Occurs 54 times. Always God as subject. Used for: (1) initial creation (Gen 1:1), (2) humans (Gen 1:27), (3) new things (Isa 48:7). Emphasizes divine initiative and novelty.

keyPassages.significance: In the beginning God created - absolute beginning.
Thus says YHWH who created you, O Jacob.

entries.theologicalNote: Bara is God's alone - humans make (asah), form (yatsar), but only God creates (bara). Creation is ex nihilo (from nothing). God creates both cosmos and His people. New creation language applies to salvation.

entries.etymology: General verb for making or doing. Unlike bara, used of both divine and human activity.
entries.otUsage: Occurs 2,633 times - very common. God makes (Gen 1:7), humans make (Gen 3:7). Used for: (1) manufacturing (Exod 25:10), (2) performing (Gen 18:19), (3) producing (Gen 1:11). Versatile action word.

keyPassages.significance: God made the expanse.

keyPassages.hebrew: כִּי שֵׁשֶׁת־יָמִים עָשָׂה יְהוָה אֶת־הַשָּׁמַיִם וְאֶת־הָאָרֶץ
keyPassages.significance: In six days YHWH made heaven and earth.

entries.theologicalNote: Asah complements bara in creation accounts. God makes from existing materials; He creates from nothing. Humans are called to 'do' God's will - asah Torah. Making implies purposeful activity.

entries.etymology: Potter's word - to shape clay. The careful, artistic forming of material. Also 'devise/purpose.'
entries.otUsage: Occurs 63 times. Used for: (1) potter forming clay (Isa 29:16), (2) God forming man (Gen 2:7), (3) God forming animals (Gen 2:19), (4) devising plans (Ps 94:20). Artisan craftsmanship.

keyPassages.hebrew: וַיִּיצֶר יְהוָה אֱלֹהִים אֶת־הָאָדָם עָפָר מִן־הָאֲדָמָה
keyPassages.significance: YHWH God formed man from dust of the ground.

keyPassages.hebrew: יְהוָה אָבִינוּ אָתָּה אֲנַחְנוּ הַחֹמֶר וְאַתָּה יֹצְרֵנוּ
keyPassages.significance: YHWH, You are our Father; we are the clay, You are our Potter.

entries.theologicalNote: God as Potter shapes His people. Humans are dust artistically formed. The Potter has rights over the clay (Rom 9:21). God also 'forms' purposes - plans shaped with intention.

entries.etymology: Dual form (always plural). The heights, the lofty. Where rain comes from and where God dwells.
entries.otUsage: Occurs 421 times. Means: (1) physical sky (Gen 1:1), (2) atmosphere (Gen 1:20), (3) God's dwelling (1 Kings 8:30). 'Heaven and earth' = everything. 'Heavens of heavens' = highest heaven.

keyPassages.hebrew: בְּרֵאשִׁית בָּרָא אֱלֹהִים אֵת הַשָּׁמַיִם וְאֵת הָאָרֶץ
keyPassages.significance: God created the heavens and the earth.
The heavens declare the glory of God.

entries.theologicalNote: Heaven is both physical sky and God's realm. Heaven and earth together mean the whole created order. The heavens declare God's glory. 'New heavens and new earth' is eschatological hope.

entries.etymology: From root meaning 'be firm.' The solid ground, territory, or the whole earth.
entries.otUsage: Occurs 2,504 times - very common. Means: (1) whole earth (Gen 1:1), (2) dry land (Gen 1:10), (3) specific land (Gen 12:1 - land of Canaan), (4) ground (Gen 1:25). Central to covenant.

keyPassages.significance: The heavens and the earth - all creation.
Go... to the land I will show you.

entries.theologicalNote: The land (erets) is promised to Abraham's seed. 'The earth is YHWH's' (Ps 24:1). Exile from land is judgment; return is restoration. 'Inherit the earth' is messianic promise.

entries.etymology: From root meaning 'roar.' The roaring sea. Also means 'west' (Mediterranean was to the west).
entries.otUsage: Occurs 396 times. Means: (1) sea (Gen 1:10), (2) west direction (Gen 28:14), (3) large basin (1 Kings 7:23 - 'bronze sea'). Red Sea (yam suph) in Exodus. Leviathan in the sea.

keyPassages.hebrew: וַיֹּולֶךְ יְהוָה אֶת־הַיָּם בְּרוּחַ קָדִים עַזָּה
keyPassages.significance: YHWH drove back the sea - the parting.
The sea is His, for He made it.

entries.theologicalNote: The sea represents chaos subdued by God. Parting the sea demonstrates mastery over chaos. In new creation, 'the sea is no more' (Rev 21:1). God sets boundaries for the sea.

entries.etymology: Possibly from 'lofty.' The elevated terrain. Place of divine encounter.
entries.otUsage: Occurs 558 times. Refers to: (1) specific mountains (Sinai, Zion, Carmel), (2) hill country (Num 13:17), (3) symbolic mountains (Isa 2:2). Mountains are meeting places with God.

keyPassages.significance: Mount Sinai was wrapped in smoke - theophany.

keyPassages.hebrew: אֶשָּׂא עֵינַי אֶל־הֶהָרִים מֵאַיִן יָבֹא עֶזְרִי
keyPassages.significance: I lift my eyes to the hills - where does my help come from?

entries.theologicalNote: Mountains are theophany sites - Sinai, Carmel, Zion. They represent stability and divine presence. Zion is God's holy mountain. 'Mountain of YHWH' will be exalted above all (Isa 2:2).

entries.etymology: From נָהַר (nahar) - to flow. A continuously flowing watercourse. Rivers define geography.
entries.otUsage: Occurs 120 times. Refers to: (1) Euphrates ('the River' - Gen 15:18), (2) rivers generally (Gen 2:10), (3) metaphorical streams (Ps 46:4). Rivers mark boundaries and provide life.

keyPassages.significance: A river went out of Eden to water the garden.
There is a river whose streams make glad the city of God.

entries.theologicalNote: Eden had a life-giving river. The Promised Land extends to 'the River' (Euphrates). The eschatological river flows from the temple (Ezek 47). Rivers symbolize life, blessing, and boundaries.

entries.etymology: From דָּבַר (davar) - possibly 'place of driving' (flocks). Uninhabited grazing land.
entries.otUsage: Occurs 271 times. Means: (1) desert (Deut 8:2), (2) pastureland (Ps 65:12), (3) uninhabited land (Jer 9:2). Israel's formative experience was in the wilderness.

keyPassages.hebrew: אֲשֶׁר הוֹלִיכֲךָ יְהוָה אֱלֹהֶיךָ זֶה אַרְבָּעִים שָׁנָה בַּמִּדְבָּר
keyPassages.significance: YHWH your God led you forty years in the wilderness.

keyPassages.hebrew: קוֹל קוֹרֵא בַּמִּדְבָּר פַּנּוּ דֶּרֶךְ יְהוָה
keyPassages.significance: A voice cries in the wilderness: Prepare the way of YHWH.

entries.theologicalNote: The wilderness is place of testing, dependence, and encounter with God. Israel was formed in the midbar. John the Baptist prepares 'in the wilderness.' Wilderness can be place of both judgment and renewal.

entries.etymology: From עָצָה (atsah) - be firm, close. The solid, firm plant. Both living tree and cut wood.
entries.otUsage: Occurs 330 times. Means: (1) tree (Gen 1:11), (2) wood/timber (Gen 6:14), (3) gallows (Esth 5:14). 'Tree of life' and 'tree of knowledge' are central. Fruitfulness symbolized by trees.

keyPassages.hebrew: וְעֵץ הַחַיִּים בְּתוֹךְ הַגָּן וְעֵץ הַדַּעַת
keyPassages.significance: The tree of life in the midst of the garden, and the tree of knowledge.
He shall be like a tree planted by streams of water.

entries.theologicalNote: The tree of life represents eternal life. The righteous are like fruitful trees (Ps 1). Christ hung on a 'tree' (Deut 21:23; Acts 5:30). In new creation, the tree of life reappears (Rev 22:2).

entries.etymology: From פָּרָה (parah) - be fruitful. The product of growth - literal or metaphorical.
entries.otUsage: Occurs 119 times. Means: (1) tree fruit (Gen 1:11), (2) offspring (Deut 7:13), (3) results/consequences (Prov 1:31). 'Be fruitful and multiply.' Fruit of lips, womb, hands, etc.

keyPassages.significance: Be fruitful and multiply - creation mandate.

keyPassages.hebrew: הִנֵּה נַחֲלַת יְהוָה בָּנִים פְּרִי הַבֶּטֶן
keyPassages.significance: Children are a heritage from YHWH, the fruit of the womb.

entries.theologicalNote: Fruitfulness is blessing. 'Be fruitful' is humanity's first command. 'Fruit of the Spirit' uses this imagery. Bearing fruit requires abiding (John 15). The forbidden fruit brought death; the tree of life gives life.

entries.etymology: From root meaning 'be dumb.' Animals as non-speaking creatures. Domestic animals especially.
entries.otUsage: Occurs 190 times. Means: (1) domestic animals (Gen 1:24), (2) cattle (Exod 9:4), (3) beasts (Ps 49:12). Distinguished from wild beasts (chayyah). 'Behemoth' in Job 40.

keyPassages.significance: Let the earth bring forth living creatures... livestock.

keyPassages.hebrew: צֹנֶה וַאֲלָפִים כֻּלָּם וְגַם בַּהֲמוֹת שָׂדָי
keyPassages.significance: Sheep and oxen, all of them, and also beasts of the field.

entries.theologicalNote: Humans have dominion over animals. Animals also receive Sabbath rest. Clean/unclean animals teach discernment. Animals will share in new creation peace (Isa 11:6-9).

entries.etymology: From עוּף (uph) - to fly. Flying creatures, primarily birds but can include flying insects.
entries.otUsage: Occurs 71 times. Means: (1) birds (Gen 1:21), (2) flying creatures (Lev 11:20), (3) fowl (1 Kings 4:33). Clean and unclean birds (Lev 11). Birds used in sacrifice and symbolism.

keyPassages.significance: Let birds fly above the earth across the expanse.
Even the sparrow has found a home - at God's altar.

entries.theologicalNote: Birds testify to God's provision (Matt 6:26). The dove signals peace (Noah) and Spirit (Jesus' baptism). Eagles symbolize strength and renewal. Ravens fed Elijah. Even birds find home at God's altar.

entries.etymology: Possibly from דָּגָה (dagah) - to multiply. Fish as prolific creatures. Dagon was a fish god.
entries.otUsage: Occurs 19 times. Refers to fish generally (Gen 1:26). The 'great fish' (dagah gadol) swallowed Jonah. Fish Gate of Jerusalem. Fish in Egypt (Num 11:5).

keyPassages.significance: Let them have dominion over the fish of the sea.

keyPassages.hebrew: וַיְמַן יְהוָה דָּג גָּדוֹל לִבְלֹעַ אֶת־יוֹנָה
keyPassages.significance: YHWH appointed a great fish to swallow Jonah.

entries.theologicalNote: Humanity has dominion over fish. Jonah's fish was God's instrument of discipline and deliverance. Early Christians used fish (ichthys) as symbol. Fish multiply greatly - 'fishers of men.'

entries.etymology: From אוֹר (or) - to be luminous. The phenomenon of light that dispels darkness.
entries.otUsage: Occurs 122 times. Means: (1) physical light (Gen 1:3), (2) dawn (Judg 16:2), (3) life (Ps 56:13), (4) divine presence (Ps 27:1). Light is first creation act. 'Let there be light.'

keyPassages.significance: God said, 'Let there be light,' and there was light.
YHWH is my light and my salvation.

entries.theologicalNote: Light is first creation - precedes even sun and moon. God is light (1 John 1:5). Light symbolizes truth, goodness, life. Walking in light means moral uprightness. Jesus is 'light of the world.'

entries.etymology: From חָשַׁךְ (chashak) - to be dark. Absence of light - physical or metaphorical.
entries.otUsage: Occurs 80 times. Means: (1) physical darkness (Gen 1:2), (2) ignorance (Job 37:19), (3) judgment/disaster (Isa 8:22), (4) death (Ps 88:12). Darkness on the deep before creation.

keyPassages.significance: Darkness was over the face of the deep.

keyPassages.hebrew: הָעָם הַהֹלְכִים בַּחֹשֶׁךְ רָאוּ אוֹר גָּדוֹל
keyPassages.significance: The people walking in darkness have seen a great light.

entries.theologicalNote: Darkness precedes light in creation - chaos before order. Darkness symbolizes ignorance, evil, judgment. The ninth plague was darkness. Yet light overcomes darkness. Even darkness is light to God (Ps 139:12).

entries.etymology: Possibly from root meaning 'minister, serve.' The sun as servant providing light and heat.
entries.otUsage: Occurs 134 times. Means: (1) sun (Gen 15:12), (2) east (Num 21:11). Note: Created on day 4, not source of light (Gen 1:16). 'Under the sun' in Ecclesiastes means earthly life.

keyPassages.significance: God made the two great lights - sun and moon (not named).

keyPassages.hebrew: וְזָרְחָה לָכֶם יִרְאֵי שְׁמִי שֶׁמֶשׁ צְדָקָה
keyPassages.significance: The sun of righteousness shall rise with healing in its wings.

entries.theologicalNote: Sun is not deity (created day 4, unnamed in Gen 1). It serves God's purposes. Joshua commanded sun to stand still. 'Sun of righteousness' is messianic. In new creation, God's glory replaces sun (Rev 21:23).

entries.etymology: From root meaning 'wander' - the wandering body in the sky. Hebrew month (yerach) related.
entries.otUsage: Occurs 27 times. The 'lesser light' ruling night (Gen 1:16). New moon festivals (Num 28:11). Moon will be darkened in judgment (Joel 2:31). Calendar based on lunar cycles.

keyPassages.significance: The lesser light to rule the night.
The moon and stars to rule by night.

entries.theologicalNote: Moon marks festivals and seasons. Not worshiped (created thing, not creator). Darkened moon signals cosmic judgment. The monthly cycle structures Israel's calendar. Stability of sun and moon = God's faithfulness.

entries.etymology: Possibly from root meaning 'be hot' - the warm period. One of most common Hebrew words.
entries.otUsage: Occurs over 2,300 times. Can mean daylight hours, 24-hour period, or era ('day of the LORD'). First word defined in Scripture (Gen 1:5). Key phrase 'this day' marks covenant moments.

keyPassages.significance: God called the light Day - first definition in Scripture.
These words shall be on your heart (referring to 'this day').

entries.theologicalNote: Day of creation debate (literal vs. figurative). 'Day of the LORD' is judgment theme (Joel, Amos, Zephaniah). 'This day' emphasizes present moment of decision. Night and day mark God's faithful ordering of time.

entries.etymology: From root meaning 'fold up' or 'wrap' - darkness wrapping the world. Some connect to לוּן (lun) - lodge.
entries.otUsage: Occurs 233 times. Period of rest and sleep but also danger. God revealed Himself in night visions (Gen 15:1, 46:2). Night watches divided sleep periods. Passover 'night of watching' (Ex 12:42).

keyPassages.significance: And the darkness he called Night.
It is a night of watching unto the LORD.

entries.theologicalNote: Night is not evil (God created darkness). Night and day praise God (Ps 19). Night represents spiritual darkness metaphorically. God gives songs in the night (Job 35:10). Protection through night watches.

entries.etymology: From בָּקַר (baqar) - seek, inquire, possibly related to light breaking through. Also connected to herding (care given at dawn).
entries.otUsage: Occurs 214 times. Time of daily sacrifice (Ex 29:39). God's mercies are new every morning (Lam 3:23). Time for prayer and seeking God. Morning = new beginning and hope.

keyPassages.significance: They are new every morning; great is your faithfulness.
O LORD, in the morning you hear my voice.

entries.theologicalNote: Morning marks renewal and fresh start. Daily sacrifice reminded Israel of daily dependence. Morning = light overcoming darkness (metaphor of hope). Psalms often written for morning worship.

entries.etymology: From עָרַב (arav) - be dark, mixed (mixing of light and dark). Same root gives 'Arabia' (west, where sun sets).
entries.otUsage: Occurs 134 times. Jewish day begins at evening (Gen 1 - 'evening and morning'). Evening sacrifice (Ex 29:39). Between the evenings = twilight for Passover lamb. Time of vulnerability.

keyPassages.significance: And there was evening and there was morning, one day.

keyPassages.hebrew: וְשָׁחֲטוּ אֹתוֹ כֹּל קְהַל עֲדַת־יִשְׂרָאֵל בֵּין הָעַרְבָּיִם
keyPassages.significance: Kill it between the evenings (twilight).

entries.theologicalNote: Day begins at sunset in Hebrew thought (creation pattern). Evening sacrifice completes daily worship. Isaac meditated in fields at evening (Gen 24:63). Time of transition and reflection.

entries.etymology: From שָׁנָה (shanah) - repeat, change. Year as recurring cycle. Same root means 'change' - year brings change of seasons.
entries.otUsage: Occurs 878 times. First mention in patriarchal ages (Gen 5). Calendar centered on agricultural and religious cycles. Jubilee year (50th), sabbatical year (7th). 'Year of the LORD's favor' (Isa 61:2).

keyPassages.significance: To proclaim the year of the LORD's favor.
Proclaim liberty throughout the land (Jubilee year).

entries.theologicalNote: Years mark God's faithfulness through generations. Sabbatical year taught trust in God. Jubilee restored land and freedom. Years of wandering (40), captivity (70) had theological significance. Year of favor = messianic hope.

entries.etymology: From חָדַשׁ (chadash) - be new. Month marked by new moon appearance. Lunar calendar = approximately 29.5 days per month.
entries.otUsage: Occurs 283 times. New moon was festival day (Num 28:11). Religious calendar begins with Nisan (Passover month). Civil calendar begins with Tishri (7th month). 12 months with occasional 13th added.

keyPassages.significance: This month shall be to you the beginning of months.
At the beginnings of your months you shall offer a burnt offering.

entries.theologicalNote: Lunar calendar connected Israel to creation order. New moon = renewal and fresh start. Passover month made new beginning for Israel (religious calendar). Monthly rhythm structured worship life.

entries.etymology: From שֶׁבַע (sheva) - seven. Week as seven-day unit. Sabbath (shabbat) completes the week.
entries.otUsage: Occurs 20 times. Seven-day creation established weekly pattern. Feast of Weeks (Shavuot) = Pentecost. Daniel's 70 weeks prophecy (Dan 9:24-27). Week reflects divine order.

keyPassages.significance: Seventy weeks are decreed upon your people.

keyPassages.hebrew: וּסְפַרְתֶּם לָכֶם מִמָּחֳרַת הַשַּׁבָּת שֶׁבַע שַׁבָּתוֹת תְּמִימֹת תִּהְיֶינָה
keyPassages.significance: Count seven complete weeks from Passover to Pentecost.

entries.theologicalNote: Week originated in creation, not astronomical observation. Seven = divine completeness. Week of years (7 years) led to sabbatical. Daniel's 70 weeks = prophetic timeline to Messiah. Week uniquely Hebraic time unit.

entries.etymology: Possibly from עָנָה (anah) - answer, respond. Time as appropriate moment for action/response.
entries.otUsage: Occurs 296 times. Distinguished from olam (duration) - et emphasizes appointed, fitting time. Famous in Ecclesiastes 3: 'a time for every purpose.' Often with prepositions: 'at that time,' 'in due time.'

keyPassages.hebrew: לַכֹּל זְמָן וְעֵת לְכָל־חֵפֶץ תַּחַת הַשָּׁמָיִם
keyPassages.significance: For everything there is a season, and a time for every matter.

keyPassages.hebrew: וּמִי יוֹדֵעַ אִם־לְעֵת כָּזֹאת הִגַּעַתְּ לַמַּלְכוּת
keyPassages.significance: Who knows whether you have come to the kingdom for such a time as this.

entries.theologicalNote: God is Lord of time and seasons. Right timing is wisdom (knowing et). Kairos (NT Greek) similar concept. Mordecai's words to Esther emphasize divine timing. Human wisdom discerns appropriate times (Eccl 8:5).

entries.etymology: From קָדַם (qadam) - precede, be in front. East = direction one faces (where sun rises). Ancient = what was before.
entries.otUsage: Occurs 87 times. Can mean geographical east or temporal past. 'From of old' = ancient times. Garden of Eden planted 'eastward' (Gen 2:8). 'Ancient of Days' (Dan 7:9) uses related term.

keyPassages.significance: Whose goings forth are from of old, from ancient days.
The eternal God is your dwelling place.

entries.theologicalNote: East associated with origins (Eden, sun rise). 'God of old' = eternal God. Prophets called Israel back to ancient paths. Messianic prophecy in Micah uses qedem for Christ's eternal origin. Ancient wisdom valued.

entries.etymology: From אַחַר (achar) - after, behind. What comes after, the end result or conclusion.
entries.otUsage: Occurs 61 times. Often in phrase 'acharit hayamim' - latter days (eschatological). Also means outcome, future, posterity. Proverbs contrasts beginning and end. Hope for 'acharit' = future hope.

keyPassages.significance: To give you a future and a hope.

keyPassages.hebrew: וְהָיָה בְּאַחֲרִית הַיָּמִים נָכוֹן יִהְיֶה הַר בֵּית־יְהוָה
keyPassages.significance: In the latter days the mountain of the LORD's house shall be established.

entries.theologicalNote: Latter days = eschatological period. Jacob's deathbed prophecy uses this phrase (Gen 49:1). Prophets describe future restoration in latter days. Hope in acharit distinguishes Israel from despair - there is always a future with God.

entries.etymology: Basic meaning 'head' extended metaphorically. Head = beginning (first), top, chief, source.
entries.otUsage: Occurs 598 times. Physical head and metaphorical extensions. Rosh Hashanah = head of year (new year). First word of Bible 'bereshit' = 'in beginning' from same root. 'Head of the corner' = cornerstone.

keyPassages.significance: In the beginning God created.

keyPassages.hebrew: אֶבֶן מָאֲסוּ הַבּוֹנִים הָיְתָה לְרֹאשׁ פִּנָּה
keyPassages.significance: The stone the builders rejected has become the head of the corner.

entries.theologicalNote: Beginning implies origin and source. God is the ultimate beginning (uncreated). Rosh as 'chief' establishes priority and authority. Messianic stone becomes head/chief cornerstone. New beginnings mark God's redemptive work.

entries.etymology: From עָלַם (alam) - hide, conceal. Time beyond the horizon, concealed from view. Indefinite past or future.
entries.otUsage: Occurs 439 times. Can mean ancient past or endless future. 'From everlasting to everlasting' (Ps 90:2). Covenant 'olam' = permanent covenant. God's love is 'olam.' New heavens 'olam.'

keyPassages.significance: From everlasting to everlasting, you are God.
He has put eternity into man's heart.

entries.theologicalNote: God alone is truly eternal. Olam in human context = lasting, but not metaphysically infinite. Eternal covenant marks God's irrevocable commitment. Eternity in hearts = human longing for transcendence that only God satisfies.

entries.etymology: From מָדַד (madad) - stretch, extend. Continuity through time without interruption.
entries.otUsage: Occurs 104 times. Used for daily offerings ('olat tamid' - continual burnt offering). Showbread 'lehem panim' always before God. Menorah burned continually. Represents unceasing worship and presence.

keyPassages.significance: A continual burnt offering throughout your generations.
I will keep your law continually, forever and ever.

entries.theologicalNote: Tamid worship reflects God's perpetual worthiness. Priests maintained unbroken worship rhythm. Personal devotion should be tamid - constant. God's presence with Israel was tamid. Constancy reflects faithfulness.

entries.etymology: From עֵת (et) - time. The specific present moment. Emphasizes immediacy and urgency.
entries.otUsage: Occurs 435 times. Often introduces turning point or decision. 'Now therefore' in covenantal contexts. Marks transition from past to present action. Can be logical ('therefore') or temporal ('at this moment').

keyPassages.significance: Now therefore fear the LORD and serve him.
But now thus says the LORD who created you.

entries.theologicalNote: 'Now' marks decision moments. Joshua's challenge: choose now. God's new word: 'now' I do new thing. Present moment is always moment of response. 'Now' in prophecy often signals transition from judgment to grace.

entries.etymology: Core meaning is center, middle. Heart as center of person. Alternate form לֵבָב (levav) identical meaning.
entries.otUsage: Occurs 853 times. Not primarily emotions (that's kidneys/bowels in Hebrew thought). Heart = mind, will, character, moral center. 'Heart' makes decisions, thinks, purposes. Shema: love with all your heart.

keyPassages.significance: Love the LORD your God with all your heart.
Guard your heart above all else.

entries.theologicalNote: Heart is moral/spiritual center in Hebrew thought. Heart can be hardened (Pharaoh) or softened (new covenant). New heart promised (Ezek 36:26). God searches hearts (1 Sam 16:7). Wisdom begins in the heart.

entries.etymology: From נָפַשׁ (naphash) - breathe, refresh. The breathing creature, the living self.
entries.otUsage: Occurs 754 times. Broad meaning: living being, self, appetite, desire, person. Animals are nephesh (Gen 1:20). Not just 'soul' in Greek sense - whole living person. 'My nephesh' often = 'I myself.'

keyPassages.significance: And man became a living soul.

keyPassages.hebrew: כְּאַיָּל תַּעֲרֹג עַל־אֲפִיקֵי־מָיִם כֵּן נַפְשִׁי תַעֲרֹג אֵלֶיךָ אֱלֹהִים
keyPassages.significance: As a deer pants for water, so my soul pants for you, O God.

entries.theologicalNote: Hebrew holistic anthropology: nephesh is not separate from body. Soul thirsts, hungers, is satisfied. Soul can be bitter, troubled, revived. Loving God with all your nephesh = entire life/desire. Soul = the whole living person.

entries.etymology: Noun form of אָהַב (ahav) - to love. Emphasizes both feeling and loyal action.
entries.otUsage: Noun occurs 55 times, verb over 200. Covers all types: God's love, romantic love (Song of Songs), family love, friendship (David/Jonathan). Love is commanded (Deut 6:5), so includes volition not just emotion.

keyPassages.significance: For love is strong as death.
Because the LORD loves you.

entries.theologicalNote: God's love is elective and faithful (chesed-love). Human love responds to divine love. Love is commanded - thus involves will, not just feeling. Love and faithfulness (chesed ve'emet) paired frequently. Love leads to obedience.

entries.etymology: From שָׂנֵא (sane) - hate. Strong aversion or hostility.
entries.otUsage: Noun occurs 17 times, verb about 145 times. Can mean intense hatred or relative preference ('Jacob I loved, Esau I hated'). Hatred of evil is commanded (Ps 97:10). Hatred without cause is condemned.

keyPassages.significance: Hatred stirs up strife.
You who love the LORD, hate evil.

entries.theologicalNote: God hates sin and injustice. Righteous hatred = hating what God hates. Hatred in family contexts often means preference (Leah 'hated' = less loved). Personal hatred is destructive. Hatred of enemies forbidden for Israel.

entries.etymology: From שָׂמַח (samach) - rejoice, be glad. Exuberant gladness, often expressed outwardly.
entries.otUsage: Occurs 94 times. Joy of harvest (Isa 9:3), wedding (Jer 7:34), worship (Ps 100:2). Joy is commanded and cultivated, not just felt. 'Joy of the LORD' is strength (Neh 8:10). Festivals were times of simchah.

keyPassages.significance: The joy of the LORD is your strength.
In your presence is fullness of joy.

entries.theologicalNote: Joy is fruit of relationship with God. Deepest joy found in God's presence. Joy survives suffering (Hab 3:17-18). Joy and worship connected - serving God with gladness. Messianic age characterized by joy.

entries.etymology: From יָגָה (yagah) - grieve, suffer. Deep inward grief and anguish.
entries.otUsage: Occurs 14 times. Often paired with sighing/groaning (Isa 35:10). Jacob's grief for Joseph. Sorrow will flee in restoration (Isa 51:11). Distinguished from physical pain - inner emotional anguish.

keyPassages.significance: And sorrow and sighing shall flee away.
You will bring down my gray hairs with sorrow to Sheol.

entries.theologicalNote: Sorrow is part of fallen world. God comforts those who mourn. Sorrow can lead to repentance (godly sorrow). Ultimate removal of sorrow promised in new creation. God keeps track of tears (Ps 56:8).

entries.etymology: From פָּחַד (pachad) - tremble, be in dread. Intense fear causing trembling.
entries.otUsage: Occurs 49 times. Strong fear, often before danger or divine presence. 'Fear of Isaac' = God of Isaac (Gen 31:42). Contrasts with yir'ah (reverential fear). Night terrors (Ps 91:5). Terror before Israel's enemies.

keyPassages.significance: Dread came upon me, and trembling.
If the Fear of Isaac (God) had not been on my side.

entries.theologicalNote: Unhealthy fear paralyzes; fear of God liberates from other fears. God's presence causes dread in enemies. 'Fear of Isaac' is divine title emphasizing God's awesomeness. Perfect love casts out tormenting fear.

entries.etymology: From יָרֵא (yare) - fear, revere. Both terror and respectful awe, depending on context.
entries.otUsage: Occurs 45 times. 'Fear of the LORD' is positive - beginning of wisdom (Prov 1:7). Not cringing terror but reverent awe leading to obedience. Associated with worship, wisdom, and covenant faithfulness.

keyPassages.significance: The fear of the LORD is the beginning of knowledge.
The fear of the LORD is the beginning of wisdom.

entries.theologicalNote: Fear of LORD is heart of OT piety. Includes awe, respect, obedience, worship. Not servile terror but reverent relationship. Fear of God overcomes fear of man. Foundation of covenant faithfulness and ethical living.

entries.shortDef: be ashamed, put to shame, disappointed
entries.etymology: Root meaning to be pale, turn white - the physical response of shame. Loss of face/honor.
entries.otUsage: Verb occurs 125 times. Shame from exposed sin, defeat, misplaced trust. Adam and Eve 'not ashamed' before fall. Idol worshipers put to shame. Those who trust God will not be ashamed.

keyPassages.significance: They were both naked and not ashamed.
Israel is saved by the LORD... you shall not be put to shame.

entries.theologicalNote: Shame entered with sin. Honor-shame culture shapes biblical worldview. God covers shame (provides garments). False gods bring shame to worshipers. Trust in God removes shame. Final salvation = no more shame.

entries.etymology: Root meaning to be vexed, grieved. Anger mixed with grief/frustration.
entries.otUsage: Occurs 54 times (verb). Israel 'provoked God to anger' through idolatry. Different from aph (hot anger) - ka'as includes grief and frustration. Hannah's rival provoked her to vexation (1 Sam 1:6).

keyPassages.significance: They made me jealous with no god; they provoked me with their idols.
Provoking me to anger with their sins.

entries.theologicalNote: God's anger is provoked by covenant unfaithfulness. Not arbitrary rage but grieved response to rejection. Human anger warned against (Eccl 7:9). Provoking God's anger has severe consequences. God is slow to anger.

entries.etymology: From קָנָא (qana) - be jealous, zealous. Intense emotion for exclusive relationship or passionate commitment.
entries.otUsage: Occurs 43 times. God is 'jealous God' (Ex 20:5) - demands exclusive worship. Phinehas' zeal (Num 25:11). Can be negative envy (Gen 37:11) or positive zeal (2 Kings 10:16). Marriage jealousy in Numbers 5.

keyPassages.hebrew: כִּי אָנֹכִי יְהוָה אֱלֹהֶיךָ אֵל קַנָּא
keyPassages.significance: For I the LORD your God am a jealous God.
He was zealous with my jealousy among them.

entries.theologicalNote: Divine jealousy = proper demand for exclusive love (not petty envy). God's zeal accomplishes His purposes (Isa 9:7). Human jealousy can be righteous (for God's honor) or sinful (envy). Zeal must be according to knowledge.

entries.etymology: From אָוָה (avah) - desire, wish. Strong desire or appetite, often with negative connotation.
entries.otUsage: Occurs 21 times. Often negative: lustful desire (Num 11:4 - 'craving'), desire that leads astray (Prov 21:26). Place name Kibroth-hattaavah = 'graves of desire.' Tree was 'desirable' to Eve (Gen 3:6).

keyPassages.significance: The rabble craved intensely.
The wicked boasts of the desires of his soul.

entries.theologicalNote: Uncontrolled desire led to fall and wilderness judgments. Righteous desires exist (Ps 21:2) but ta'avah often warns against craving. Contentment is opposite virtue. Desire must be submitted to God's will.

entries.etymology: From חָפֵץ (chaphets) - delight in, desire. Pleasure and willing choice.
entries.otUsage: Occurs 39 times. God delights in steadfast love (Mic 7:18). Sabbath called 'delight' (Isa 58:13). Can mean business affair (Eccl 3:1, 17). Positive desire - what one values and pursues with pleasure.

keyPassages.significance: But his delight is in the law of the LORD.
Call the Sabbath a delight.

entries.theologicalNote: God delights in His people and in mercy. Delighting in Torah leads to blessing. What we delight in reveals our heart. True delight found in relationship with God. Sabbath delight = rest in God.

entries.etymology: From קָוָה (qavah) - wait, look for. Root means 'cord' - hope as cord tying present to future. Rahab's cord same word.
entries.otUsage: Occurs 34 times. Hope distinguished from wishful thinking - confident expectation. 'There is hope for your future' (Jer 31:17). Hope and future paired (Jer 29:11). Wicked's hope perishes (Prov 10:28).

keyPassages.significance: To give you a future and a hope.

keyPassages.hebrew: כִּי אִם־יֵשׁ אַחֲרִית וְתִקְוָתְךָ לֹא תִכָּרֵת
keyPassages.significance: Surely there is a future, and your hope will not be cut off.

entries.theologicalNote: Biblical hope is not uncertain wish but confident expectation based on God's character. Hope connects to 'latter end' - eschatological hope. Hope in God never disappoints (Ps 25:3). Without God, no true hope.

entries.etymology: From בָּטַח (batach) - trust, be confident. State of security and confidence.
entries.otUsage: Occurs 42 times (adverb 'securely' common). Dwell safely in the land (Lev 25:18). False trust in wealth, military, idols condemned. True security found only in trusting God. 'Trusts in the LORD' = core OT faith.

keyPassages.significance: Trust in the LORD with all your heart.

keyPassages.hebrew: בְּשָׁלוֹם יַחְדָּו אֶשְׁכְּבָה וְאִישָׁן כִּי־אַתָּה יְהוָה לְבָדָד לָבֶטַח תּוֹשִׁיבֵנִי
keyPassages.significance: In peace I will both lie down and sleep, for you alone make me dwell in safety.

entries.theologicalNote: Trust is relational - faith expressed in action. Misplaced trust brings destruction. Trusting God contrasts with self-reliance. Dwelling securely is covenant blessing. Trust brings peace and rest.

entries.etymology: Primary root for hatred. Strong aversion, hostility, rejection.
entries.otUsage: Occurs 147 times. God hates evil, injustice, false worship. Can express preference (Leah 'hated' vs loved). Enemies hate Israel and the righteous. Commanded to hate evil (Amos 5:15) but not personal vengeance.

keyPassages.significance: Hate evil and love good.
But Esau I hated (in contrast to Jacob).

entries.theologicalNote: Hatred of evil is righteous. 'Jacob loved, Esau hated' is relative preference in election. Hatred of enemies was permitted in OT but transformed by Jesus. God's 'hatred' expresses rejection of sin.

entries.shortDef: be pleased with, accept favorably, delight in
entries.etymology: Root meaning be favorable, accept. Divine and human pleasure/acceptance.
entries.otUsage: Occurs 56 times. God is pleased with righteous offerings (Ps 51:19). Land enjoys sabbaths (Lev 26:34). Acceptance of prayer and sacrifice. Favor and good will. 'Year of favor' (Isa 61:2).

keyPassages.significance: You do not delight in sacrifice, or I would give it.
When the LORD is pleased with a man's ways.

entries.theologicalNote: God's pleasure is in obedience over sacrifice. Accepted by God = highest blessing. Favor comes through right relationship. Divine acceptance is gracious, not earned. Christ is Son in whom Father is well pleased.

entries.etymology: Root means 'heavy' - someone with weight/substance is honored. Same root as kavod (glory).
entries.otUsage: Occurs 116 times. 'Honor your father and mother' (Ex 20:12). To honor = treat as weighty, important. Opposite: make light of (qalal). Pharaoh's heart 'heavy' = hardened (same root). Honor given to elders, parents, God.

keyPassages.significance: Honor your father and your mother.
Those who honor me I will honor.

entries.theologicalNote: Honor reflects recognition of worth. Honoring God = proper worship response. Dishonoring = treating as light/worthless. Fifth commandment: honor parents. God honors those who honor Him. Glory (kavod) from same root.

entries.etymology: Basic root for speech. Used thousands of times for quoted speech throughout OT.
entries.otUsage: Occurs over 5,300 times - most common verb introducing speech. 'And God said' begins creation (Gen 1:3). 'Thus says the LORD' introduces prophetic oracle. Covers saying, commanding, promising, thinking (saying to oneself).

keyPassages.significance: And God said, 'Let there be light.'
Come now, let us reason together, says the LORD.

entries.theologicalNote: God's word creates reality. Prophetic 'thus says' carries divine authority. Speech is powerful - blessing, cursing, promising. What one 'says in heart' = thinks. God's word never returns empty.

entries.etymology: Piel of דָּבַר (davar). More formal, deliberate speech than amar. Often for authoritative pronouncement.
entries.otUsage: Occurs 1,140 times. 'And the LORD spoke to Moses' (frequent formula). Speaking covenant words. More formal than amar. Noun davar (word) from same root. Speaking on behalf of another (Moses for God).

keyPassages.significance: And God answered him by voice (spoke audibly).
With him I speak mouth to mouth.

entries.theologicalNote: God speaks - revelation is verbal. Moses' unique status: God spoke directly to him. False prophets speak what God hasn't spoken. Speaking for God requires authenticity. Divine speech carries creative and judicial power.

entries.etymology: Primary word for movement, journey. Metaphorically for manner of life.
entries.otUsage: Occurs over 1,550 times. Literal walking and metaphorical 'walk with God' (Gen 5:24). 'Walk in my statutes' = obedient lifestyle. 'Walk after other gods' = idolatry. Jewish law is 'halakha' from this root.

keyPassages.significance: Enoch walked with God.
And walk humbly with your God.

entries.theologicalNote: Walking = living, conduct, lifestyle. Walking with God = intimate relationship and obedience. Halakha = Jewish legal tradition (how to walk). Walking in truth vs walking in darkness. Life is a journey with God.

entries.etymology: Primary word for arrival and entry. Opposite of yatsa (go out).
entries.otUsage: Occurs over 2,570 times. 'Coming in and going out' = daily life (Deut 28:6). Enter the land, enter the temple, come before God. 'The coming one' = messianic figure. Sun 'comes' (sets) at evening.

keyPassages.significance: Come into the ark, you and your household.
Behold, your king is coming to you.

entries.theologicalNote: Coming into God's presence = worship. Entry to promised land fulfilled promises. 'Coming one' is messianic hope. Jesus' entry on donkey fulfilled Zechariah 9:9. Coming and going under God's blessing = secure life.

entries.etymology: Primary word for exit and emergence. Opposite of bo (come, enter).
entries.otUsage: Occurs over 1,070 times. Exodus = 'going out' of Egypt. Sun 'goes forth.' Word 'goes out' from God's mouth. Going out to battle. Birth = child 'goes forth' from womb. Coming out of slavery to freedom.

keyPassages.hebrew: זָכוֹר אֶת־הַיּוֹם הַזֶּה אֲשֶׁר יְצָאתֶם מִמִּצְרַיִם
keyPassages.significance: Remember this day when you came out from Egypt.

keyPassages.hebrew: כֵּן יִהְיֶה דְבָרִי אֲשֶׁר יֵצֵא מִפִּי
keyPassages.significance: So shall my word be that goes out from my mouth.

entries.theologicalNote: Exodus is paradigmatic salvation event - going out from bondage. God's word goes forth accomplishing His purpose. Going out to battle required faith. Liberation theme: going out from bondage to freedom.

entries.etymology: Primary word for standing upright or taking a stand.
entries.otUsage: Occurs 524 times. Stand before God in service or judgment. Stand firm in battle. Pillar (ammud) from same root. Stand and see salvation (Ex 14:13). Things that 'stand' endure through time.

keyPassages.significance: Stand firm and see the salvation of the LORD.
The wicked will not stand in the judgment.

entries.theologicalNote: Standing before God = serving, worshiping, or being judged. Standing firm in faith is commanded. What stands = what endures. Cannot stand before God's wrath without grace. Priests stood to minister.

entries.etymology: Primary word for seated position and settled dwelling.
entries.otUsage: Occurs over 1,080 times. Sitting enthroned (God, king). Dwelling in land of promise. Sitting in judgment. Inhabitant (yoshev). 'Dwell in the land' = covenant blessing. God 'dwells' with His people.

keyPassages.significance: He who dwells in the shelter of the Most High.
He who sits in the heavens laughs.

entries.theologicalNote: God sits enthroned - sovereign. Dwelling in land = covenant blessing, exile = curse. Dwelling with God = protection and intimacy. God 'tabernacles' (shakan) related to dwelling. Sitting in gate = judging.

entries.shortDef: lie down, sleep, rest, be intimate
entries.etymology: Primary word for reclining position - sleep, rest, death, intimacy.
entries.otUsage: Occurs 213 times. Lie down to sleep. Death as 'sleeping with fathers.' Sexual intimacy. Livestock lying down = peace. 'None shall make them afraid' and they lie down safely. Rest and vulnerability.

keyPassages.significance: In peace I will lie down and sleep.
You will lie down and none will make you afraid.

entries.theologicalNote: Lying down safely = peace, security (covenant blessing). Death described as lying down with ancestors. Sexual laws use this term. Rest depends on trusting God. Fear prevents rest; faith enables it.

entries.etymology: Primary word for rising from seated or lying position. Also establish, confirm.
entries.otUsage: Occurs 628 times. Rise from sleep, rise to action, rise against enemies. 'Arise and go' - call to action. Establish covenant (hiphil). Rise from dead implied in some contexts. Opposite of fall.

keyPassages.significance: Arise, shine, for your light has come.
I will establish my covenant.

entries.theologicalNote: God calls His people to arise. Resurrection hope uses this imagery (Dan 12:2). God establishes His covenant. Rising = readiness for action. 'A star shall arise from Jacob' (Num 24:17) = messianic hope.

entries.etymology: Basic word for taking possession, receiving, acquiring.
entries.otUsage: Occurs 967 times. Take a wife (marry). Take hold of. Receive instruction (Prov 1:3). God 'took' Enoch, Elijah (translation). Take and eat. Taking territory. Learning = receiving teaching.

keyPassages.significance: For God took him (Enoch).
To receive instruction in wise dealing.

entries.theologicalNote: Taking instruction = becoming wise. God 'taking' can mean death or translation. Taking a wife = covenantal marriage. Receiving what God gives. Balance with natan (give) in covenant relationship.

entries.etymology: Basic word for giving, placing, making to be. Wide semantic range.
entries.otUsage: Occurs over 2,000 times. Give land, give law, give offspring. Set in place. Make someone to be. God is ultimate giver. 'Gift of God' = nathan-el (Nathaniel). Giving thanks.

keyPassages.significance: And God set them in the expanse of the heavens.
And I will give you a new heart.

entries.theologicalNote: God is supreme giver - land, law, offspring, salvation, new heart. Every good gift from God. Names with nathan: Nathaniel, Jonathan, Elnnathan. Giving back to God what He first gave. Generosity reflects divine character.

entries.etymology: Primary word for sending, dispatching, extending.
entries.otUsage: Occurs 847 times. Send messengers, send plagues, send away. Stretch out hand. Let people go (Exodus). 'Here am I, send me' (Isa 6:8). Sending out with authority to act for sender.

keyPassages.significance: Here am I! Send me.
I will send you to Pharaoh.

entries.theologicalNote: God sends His servants with His authority. Prophetic sending requires divine commission. 'Apostle' (shaliach) = sent one with sender's authority. Jesus as ultimate 'Sent One' from Father. Being sent implies mission.
